PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. The present Australian national flag is not distinctively and uniquely Australian and is confused with other national flags.
2. The people of Australia have never had an opportunity to express their views on an appropriate Australian national flag in a referendum.
3. The present Australian national flag does not properly represent Australia as a sovereign, independent nation.
4. The present Australian national flag incorrectly proclaims Australia as a colony, homeland, protectorate, dominion or government department of Great Britain.
5. The first condition in the flag competition of 1901 required that the design should show Australia's loyalty to the British Empire. The British Empire no longer exists.
6. A public opinion poll held in 1984 using the Gallup Method revealed that 52% of Australians surveyed wanted a competition for a new design for the Australian flag.
7. There is no inherent link between Australia proclaiming a unique and distinctive flag and the political issue of Australia moving to a republican form of government.
8. The adoption of a truly Australian national flag would serve as a focal point for Australia's bicentennial celebrations in 1988.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
(a) Appoint a Committee of the Parliament with representatives from both Houses and all parties to invite and consider proposals for the design of a new Australian national flag, and

(b) Require that Committee to make recommendations on the form of a minimum cost referendum in which the electors will be given the opportunity to vote for a flag from a selection of at least three designs, one of which will be the present Australian national flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The speech read as follows-
This Bill amends various Acts concerned with crime, law enforcement and criminal justice.

Earlier this year in the 2nd term of the Hawke Labor Government the weaponry against criminals who seek to undermine the honest endeavours of the overwhelming majority of law-abiding citizens of this country was greatly strengthened. The Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 is now law and the Government is confident that it will contribute greatly in our fight against crime. The Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 has also been enacted and it will ensure that the criminal will not find sanctuary by merely removing evidence or the proceeds of his or her criminal activities offshore.

This legislative armoury will be enhanced by the Cash Transaction Reports Bill 1987, which is shortly to be re-introduced into this Parliament, and by modern extradition legislation. The Bill now before the Senate is not as grand in scope as those pieces of legislation. It is nevertheless important in maintaining this Government's momentum and commitment to monitoring and reforming the laws relating to crime and criminal justice in Australia.

To mention but one more instance of this Government's decisive actions in this area I note for the Senator's attention the major review of the criminal laws of the Commonwealth presently under way. This review is being chaired by the former Chief Justice of the High Court, The Rt Hon. Sir Harry Gibbs and is due to report at the end of June 1988.
I now proceed to outline the important elements of this Bill.
Amendments of the Christmas Island Act 1958

Mr President, the amendments to the Christmas Island Act contained in Part 2 of the Bill are part of the legislative package developed by my colleagues the Minister for the Department of Arts, Sports, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, and the Attorney-General. It addresses deficiencies in Christmas Island law highlighted by recent events in the Territory.

The Island became an Australian Territory in 1958. Before then it had been a part of the Colony of Singapore and then, briefly, a separate colony. On the Island's separation from Singapore, trial by jury was abolished in the Island's courts, as it was believed that, in a community of fewer then 2,000 adults, there was not a sufficient assurance of obtaining eligible, impartial jurors. The absence of a majority language and the estimate that only about 330 of the 2,000 adult Islanders speak English well enough to be able to understand a trial in English and deliberate in the jury room in English present additional problems. When a Supreme court for the Territory was established in 1958, the Australian Government of the day retained trial by judge alone. There has only been one criminal trial on indictment on the Island since 1958.

Mr President, this Government does not believe that the people of Christmas Island should continue to be denied the right to trial by jury. The fact that in a particular case difficulties may arise in empanelling an impartial English speaking jury does not provide a justification for denying to the Islanders the right to trial by jury conferred on other Australians. Accordingly, a juries ordinance has been made for the Territory which establishes a system of trial by jury selected from eligible Island residents which will apply to future trials on indictment conducted on the Island.

The Bill now before the Senate enshrines the right to trial by jury for indictable Territory offences. This right will no longer be able to be removed by ordinance, as was done in 1958, but only by Act of this Parliament. Furthermore, Mr President in recognition of the potential difficulty in empanelling a jury on the Island to try a particular case, the Bill now before the Senate will enable the Supreme Court of Christmas Island, where the interests of justice so require, to sit in a State or Territory for the purpose of conducting a trial there with jurors drawn from the jury list prepared for that place.

This is similar to the scheme applicable to a trial by jury in the High Court and the Federal Court in a State or Territory. The jury is summoned by Federal officials using State or Territory jury lists, and the cost is borne by the Commonwealth Government.
Amendments of the Crimes Act 1914

Mr President, the Bill amends the Crimes Act 1914 in four main areas. Firstly, various interpretative provisions concerned with criminal law are relocated into the Act from the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. The intention here is to improve accessibility to the law and reinforce the Crimes Act as the most important Commonwealth criminal law. Some of the relocated provisions are amended to clarify and simplify them. Worthy of particular mention are proposed sections 4G to 4J. These deal with the classification of indictable and summary offences and provide for a step-down mechanism to apply, in the absence of contrary intention, to all Commonwealth offences punishable by not more than 10 years imprisonment. This will enable many more indictable offences to be dealt with summarily. The penalties available where the step down mechanism operates are reduced. The procedure can be adopted only with the defendant's consent unless the charge relates to property the value of which does not exceed $500. Where the defendant's consent is not required, the Court decides the issue of whether it is appropriate to use the `step-down' mechanism. Presently such step-down mechanisms exist but they are res-stricted to offences against the Crimes Act.

These measures, Mr President, provide some relief to defendants charged with less serious breaches of offence provisions carrying high pe-nalties and may have implications for reducing court delays whilst recognising the importance of jury trial in our society.

Secondly, the Crimes Act is amended by terminating the application of the provisions crea-ting inchoate offences in their application to offences against laws of the Australian Capital Territory and the external territories. This removes an impediment to the Government's program for the distribution of syringes by pharmacists and others to check the spread of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. Pre-sently, no territory law can give the pharmacists protection from criminal liability which, because of the constitutional paramountcy of Commonwealth law, now arises under the Crimes Act. Where necessary, replacement inchoate offences will be inserted into territory laws.
Thirdly, section 10 of the Crimes Act is amended to:
(i) clarify that search warrants issued pursuant to it can apply to vehicles and aircraft;
(ii) place beyond doubt that, when executing a warrant, police may break open internal doors and receptacles where this is reasonable and necessary; and
(iii) enable a search warrant to be issued 72 hours before the sought after items are likely to be at the particular premises to be searched.

Mr President, this last amendment does not alter the onus on the police when applying for a warrant, but merely alters the time at which a warrant may be sought. It will aid law enforcement by, for example, enabling police, who have received information that drugs will be delivered to certain premises, to obtain a search warrant in advance. This warrant can then be executed at the operationally most advantageous time.

Fourthly, the enactment of the amendments contained in clauses 16 and 17 will provide a comprehensive Commonwealth legislative scheme dealing with escape and related offences for which appropriate penalties are prescribed.

The offences will cover a person who is arrested, a person in lawful custody or a person detained during the pleasure of the Governor-General for an offence against the law of the Commonwealth or a territory. The proposed provisions increase the ambit of the existing offences of escape and aiding or permitting another person to escape, as well as creating new offences of forcibly rescuing a person in custody, being at large unlawfully and knowingly harbouring or employing an escapee. Because Territory offenders will be covered by the new provisions of the Crimes Act 1914, consequential amendments have been made to the Removal of Prisoners (Territories) Act 1923, and the Removal of Prisoners (Australian Capital Territory) Act 1968.
Amendments of the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978

The underlying purpose of the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978 is to prevent persons from Australia becoming involved in hostile activity in overseas countries. The purpose of the amendments is to remedy a number of deficiencies in the Act. One such deficiency is that mercenary acts as such are not proscribed unless they involve acts done for specific purposes, those purposes generally relating to acts directed against the government of a foreign country. The scope of the Act is further limited in that the definition of government is limited to those governments recognised by Australia. The term `government' has been redefined to refer to governments which are in effective control of a country. The definition of foreign country is being omitted and a new definition of foreign State is being substituted to overcome possible limits as to the application of the Act to incursions into particular geographical areas outside Australia. In addition, two new offences have been created-prohibiting persons from Australia from engaging in armed hostilities outside Australia and prohibiting the use of a vessel or aircraft in preparations for an incursion into an overseas country.

Subsection 6 (4) of the Act has the effect of excluding from the former prohibition persons serving in the armed forces of a government, or an armed force in respect of which a declaration by the Minister is in force.

Other amendments are designed to meet a number of difficulties in relation to prosecutions under the Act involving the preparation for or incursion into an overseas country. Those amendments provide for the use of ministerial certificates in respect of a number of matters in a prosecution and amend section 7 of the Act, which prohibits preparations for incursions into an overseas country, to ensure that proof of an offence against that section does not depend on proof of an offence against section 6, which prohibits such incursions by a person from Australia.

The Minister will be allowed greater flexibility when permitting persons to recruit in Australia for service in an overseas armed force, being able to impose conditions on that permission. The penalties for a breach of the prohibition on recruiting are also increased. Finally, for the avoidance of doubt, the amendments make it clear that the provision of humanitarian aid by persons from Australia is not an offence.
Amendments of the Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act 1976

The Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act 1976 has proved unsuitable in bringing prosecutions in two recent cases-the bomb attack on the building housing the Turkish Consulate General in Melbourne in 1986 and a threat made against the Pope in Adelaide in 1986.

The Government takes the view that acts of political terrorism should be prosecuted under Commonwealth legislation and that the Commonwealth should have legislation which will enable it to discharge its international responsibility for diplomatic and consular protection.

The amendments of the Act contained in Part 5 of the Bill are designed to provide a more comprehensive set of offences to cover acts which may be committed against an Internationally Protected Person or property connected with an Internationally Protected Person and to provide appropriate penalties for those offences. The intention relevant to those offences has been defined and in future the question of whether a person is an Internationally Protected Person for the purposes of a prosecution will be determined objectively.
Amendments of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987

Mr President, as I mentioned before, the Government introduced legislation on Proceeds of Crime in the Autumn Sittings which was welcomed by all Senators as a much need initiative against major crime. At that time all Senators recognized the novel nature of that legislation and the need to monitor its operation in order to ensure its continuing effectiveness.

Since the enactment of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, law enforcement agencies have idetified a number of aspects which require clarification or minor modification. Part 6 of the Bill contains amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act which address these concerns.

The Bill ensures that criminals cannot avoid the operation of statutory forfeiture by distancing themselves from the legal or equitable ownership of proceeds of crime, while retaining effective control over such property. It also limits the potential for property of a convicted person, which is in fact derived from unlawful activity, being excluded from statutory forfeiture on the technical argument that the property was not derived from the particular offence for which the criminal has been convicted.

The amendments will enable the Official Trustee to deal more effectively with tainted property placed under its custody and control, and a new section 102a is to be inserted to provide a statutory indemnification of the Official Trustee by the Commonwealth, along the lines of the indemnity provided in the Bankruptcy Act 1966.

The Bill also removes limitations on the granting of interim restraining orders. Practical experience has shown that, in relation to any property, including real estate and especially money held on call in a bank account, any notice to the defendant that dealing with such property is to be restrained extends an invitation to the defendant to deal with the property or to withdraw the funds. It should be borne in mind that such orders may only be made for a maximum period of 14 days.

Mr President, I have briefly dealt with only the more noteworthy of the amendment to the Proceeds of Crime Act. Other amendments are either to correct typescript errors, or to make minor amendments for the purpose of clarifying particular provisions.
Amendments to the Transfer of Prisoners Act 1983

The Parliamentary Counsels' Committee recommended to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General on 2 May 1985, minor amendments to the Transfer of Prisoners Act 1983. Clauses 49, 50 and 52 give effect to the Committee's recommendation. All the States and the Northern Territory have uniform interstate transfer legislation and the amendments will achieve greater uniformity with State legislation.

The proposed amendments will also enable Northern Territory prisoners transferred to South Australia under the Removal of Prisoners (Territories) Act 1923 before the transfer of prisoners scheme came into operation to be covered as Commonwealth prisoners. At present there is no mechanism for their transfer interstate either for trial or welfare purposes under either the Commonwealth Transfer of Prisoners Act or the State scheme.
Financial Impact Statement

It is not anticipated that the proposals in the Bill as a whole will occasion any increased costs to the Commonwealth. It is not possible to provide quantitative estimates of savings. However, it is anticipated that these will eventuate as a result of the proposed amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, which are designed to ensure the effective operation of that Act, and by the proposed amendments to the Crimes Act 1914, which enable certain indictable offences to be dealt with summarily, thus producing cost and time savings in Commonwealth prosecutions.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Short had moved by way of amendment:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the imposition of a fee of $5 on Australian citizens returning to their own country by international air travel is an obnoxious attack on the fundamental right of Australians to enter their own country''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Migration Amendment Bill 1987 which, at first glance, appears small, inconsequential and perhaps a matter of no great debate. It sets out to do four things; firstly, it sets out to impose a fee of $240 which must be paid prior to the reconsideration of a matter being entertained; secondly, it sets out to define closely the meaning of a request for reconsideration; thirdly it imposes a $5 so-called fee to be paid by all persons entering or re-entering Australia-including citizens entering Australia after January 1988; and, fourthly, it introduces an on the spot fine for persons carrying or being responsible for the carrying of illegal passengers. Some of those provisions are important, such as closely defining the meaning of the word `request' which had been subject to some lack of definition and the subject of a Federal Court of Australia ruling in the case of Ilyas v. the Minister for Immigration.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it is the question of the imposition of the fee of $240 which I would like particularly to address and to draw the attention of all honourable senators to. In the first place, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) said in his second reading speech that the sum of $240 is to be a fee, but he then went on to say that it is important that the regulations take effect retrospectively from 16 September, in order to protect the revenue. My understanding is that fees are a cost recovery measure and not a Budget or revenue raising measure. But the point which is particularly worrying is that dealing with retrospectivity.

Under the Acts Interpretation Act, retrospective regulations which would prejudicially affect the rights of an individual are void and of no effect. But because the Act itself makes these regulations retrospective, the Senate does not have the power to table and disallow those regulations. It is a novel way of drafting, which has no precedent. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has pointed that out, in its report tabled yesterday. Upon researching, it found no precedent at all for this form of drafting. What it does, in effect, is to avoid or evade the provisions of section 48 (2) of the Acts Interpretation Act, which is put there very deliberately to protect the rights of individuals.

In the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, of which I am pleased to be Deputy Chairman, there is concern from time to time when we look at regulations as to whether or not any retrospective effect prejudicially affects the rights of individuals, and whether or not a proposed amendment to that Act may have highlighted a problem that already exists. Should this become a normal manner of drafting, should this become the ordinary way in which regulations with a retrospective effect are to be introduced, then the Committee and the Senate itself will be powerless to do anything about the prejudice of the rights of individuals by the regulation-making power.

Regarding the sum of $240, I would like to point out to the Senate that the Minister said in his second reading speech that the $240 has been struck so that that sum is in line with the fee for all appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. However, that fee was until recently $200 and I am wondering whether this is an indication or notice that the fee for lodgment of an appeal to that Tribunal is to be raised even further. As a matter of fact, and this is also extraordinarily worrying, the fee of $240 is already being charged for lodgment of applications for reconsideration of decisions concerning migration matters. Clearly, this is illegal. There is no justification for it and yet it is being done as a matter of fact. The presumption is that this Bill will be passed by the Parliament, and that the $240 fee will be required retrospectively. The double whammy is that the novel drafting has not only allowed the retrospective effect to go unchallenged, but also resulted in a Government department pre-empting the will of the Parliament and putting into operation something which is not yet law.

The fact that this matter was raised in the Budget and is being justified as a Budget matter, and that this Senate has allowed retrospective revenue provisions to go through, extends what we are seeing as a practice of this Government, which is legislation by Press release. If the Press release says something will happen, it is automatic that, somewhere down the line, legislation implementing that Press release will be put in place, and therefore one must act in accordance with what the Press release says. This, in effect, is an extension of executive government by Press release, which avoids the importance of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't want to rely on it.

—Senator Watson points out quite accurately that sometimes the Press release and the subsequent legislation do not mirror each other. Suppose that we take the second reading speech at face value. We see that this is a revenue matter with the imposition of a retrospective tax. Indeed, one could say that this was the seventeenth new tax introduced by the Hawke-Keating Government since it came to office.

SPEECH.PARA: I would now like to deal with another serious point in relation to the definition section, which I mentioned at the beginning of my speech. As I said, there has been some uncertainty about what constitutes a request. The Act clearly defines that a request will now be an application in a prescribed form accompanied by the fee of $240. More worrying still is the fact that the Minister has given an indication that representation from senators and members will not be considered in any of these matters unless that representation is accompanied by a form in the prescribed manner and the $240 fee. That is a clear impingement on the rights of senators and members to represent citizens and to represent people who are non-citizens but are still within Australia's jurisdiction and our legal system, in relation to making representations for them and on their behalf. To say the least, that impingement is highly unacceptable to senators and members. The result which could flow from that is that the Minister perhaps would see that senators and members would act as advocates for and on behalf of people seeking reconsideration, which is clearly not the function of a senator or a member.

The right of the Parliament to enact legislation, which legislation is only then to be followed and put into force, has been negated in this case. The actions of the Parliament have been pre-empted and an assumption made that the legislation will simply follow the form of the Press release. Secondly, I see a danger in the interpretation of that strict definition system acting against the ability of members and senators to properly represent people in the electorate at large.

I now turn to the $5 fee. In his second reading speech, the Minister seems to want to have it both ways. The $5 fee which is being introduced for the re-entry or entry of any person, including citizens, into Australia, is a cost recovery measure and therefore is able to be dealt with by way of regulation with no maximum limit set. Again, this is clearly an infringement on proper practice. Yet the $240 fee, which I mentioned before, has been treated as a revenue raising measure and, therefore, the retrospective action is supposed to be be sanctioned by this place. The $5 fee has other problems associated with it. First, who is going to collect the fee? If it is to be collected by the carrier, which carrier, if more than one is involved in a particular journey? This fee is obnoxious in its attack on the fundamental right of Australians to re-enter their own country without having to pay a fee to exercise that right.

The fourth part of the Bill deals with the widening of the definition of `operator'. It increases the penalty from $2,000 to a maximum of $3,000 where a carrier or operator who has brought an illegal person or person without sufficient documentation into Australia may be subject to an on the spot fine. I can see that an on the spot fine could be of benefit and use, but I would like to know that the rights of the person to challenge that on the spot fine are protected, and I seek that assurance.

There is another matter which is not covered by the Bill but which is relevant in highlighting the Government's attitude. I refer to the report of the so-called privatisation of the entry of business migrants into this country. Privatisation is a misdescription because it is an abrogation of government's responsibility to determine who is a suitable person to come into this country. It is not a business enterprise which can be better handled in the private sector than in the public sector, which is always an endeavour I am pleased to see; it is the responsibility of the elected government to decide who will be a suitable migrant to this country and who will not.

With the proposed scheme the opportunities for corruption are mind-bending. Who, for instance, would be eligible for such appointments? Already discussions have gone on at various levels in this Parliament as to whether acts or regulations should specify the type of person who should be appointed to a board or office. It is generally felt that some latitude should be left to a Minister to exercise that discretion. But in the light of some of the appointments that have been made, I cannot help but be rather more specific. Who would be suitable? Would David Combe be suitable, because the Australian Labor Party has a very good record of looking after its mates? Would Mr Al Grassby, the only member of parliament ever to have a volume control on his suits, be considered suitable, particularly when one takes into account the fact that Mrs Grassby has recently had an appointment, as Senator Puplick pointed out the other day. But dare I suggest that the man with the best Korean connection of all may be considered suitable? Would Mr Morgan Ryan be considered suitable? The reason I have deliberately been more specific in this area is simply to point out that this whole proposition is a minefield and is riddled with the ability for corruption and abuse.

To sum up what I have to say about the Bill itself, it is the avoidance or the evasion of section 48 (2) of the Acts Interpretation Act which I think is the most serious matter to be addressed in this Bill. As I said, it is a novel piece of drafting, it has no precedent, and should it become the ordinary and accepted way of drafting of Bills, the protection that is afforded the rights of individuals under section 48 (2) will be negated. I find the imposition of the fee of $240, flagging an increase in all appeal fees to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, quite unacceptable. I find the extension of legislation by the Executive by Press release quite unacceptable. I find that close definition of the term `request' so that it may impinge on the rights of members and senators also unacceptable. And I strenuously oppose placing a tax on Australians to re-enter their own country. I also seek reassurance that the right to appeal against an on the spot fine as set out in the Bill would be protected.

As I said at the beginning, this is a very small Bill. At first glance it appears to be innocuous. It does some worthwhile things. I have drawn the Senate's attention to the dramatic changes in the way legislation is dealt with because I believe it is a serious matter. It is a practice that should not be allowed to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —A mechanism is about to be put in place by the Migration Amendment Bill 1987 to impose charges on people entering Australia. What will this mechanism lead to? Will it lead to charges so high that the flow of immigration could be halted? Will it lead to selective immigration? Another part of the Bill imposes a $240 charge. The Government stated in the Budget and elsewhere that no new taxes would be introduced. Can we trust the Government not to impede immigration? The second reading speech states:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 7 of the Bill establishes a mechanism whereby a new immigration clearance fee for service can be collected.

How can anyone say that this is not a tax? If he does, how can he call the departure tax a fee? I would like to know the difference. I have travelled quite a lot in the last few years, although not quite as much as some senators and members. When I travelled I paid my own way. In no place I visited was I charged a landing fee, let alone a fee to leave the place. This tax affects everyone coming into Australia. It adds another unpaid collector to the list. The first unpaid collector came into being with the pay as you earn tax. Then there was the prescribed payments tax and the sales tax. At least if one does not pay the departure tax at the airport one can now pay it at a post office. I presume that the Commonwealth pays post offices a collection fee. In the other cases I have mentioned the tax is collected for nothing and if the carriers do not do the right thing in collecting the tax, by God they cop it.

Even though Senator McKiernan might not agree with me, I consider this Bill to be an attack on immigration. Let me digress a little and refer to the value of immigration to Australia. As I mentioned in my maiden speech, I have a little knowledge of immigration, mainly immigration since World War II. Since World War II we have seen the development of Australia greatly assisted by immigration. After World War II we had 1 1/2 million migrants from the United Kingdom. We then had the European immigrants, who paid their own way. There was a certain amount of discrimination. Both groups were not treated the same. The southern European immigrants, who paid their own way, entered into a two-year contract-which I think was the case also with the #10 immigrants from the United Kingdom-whereby they would work at certain jobs in certain places, mostly in the outback. They worked in agriculture, the timber industry, on the railway gangs, on road building and in gold mining. The use of migration was probably the only way that those industries could really fill their work quotas and, as I said, get moving again after the war.

In the 1950s we saw the beginning of the building boom. These migrants, having completed their two-year apprenticeships or whatever, filtered into the building boom. There were skilled stonemasons, terrazzo workers, painters and craftsmen. Until those years probably no one in Australia had heard of terrazzo work. Terrazzo was instilled into the Australian building system by the Italian migrants. There were others. There were the Dutch with their concrete and the Germans with architectural ideas of their own. They all brought their ideas into the building projects of that era. We can still see the results of those ideas and we will do so for many years to come.

In the 1960s we had the great iron ore mining boom. It was the migrants who made the construction camps before the others who actually worked the mines arrived in those places. As those migrant workers get older and move out of the work force we see the departure of certain migrants from certain countries who did specialised jobs. I must mention the steel riggers from Latvia. I can remember that in the 1950s and 1960s almost all the riggers in the country, the bush, were Latvians. As they have moved out they have been very hard to replace. As they have been replaced the building construction costs have certainly got a lot higher. I have already mentioned that concreting work was done by the Dutch. They mainly did the walls, the big slabs and such. The finer work was done by the Italians. I am not skiting; I am just pointing out the facts.

Probably the latest boom of migration was in the 1970s after the Vietnam war. We had migrants from Vietnam and allied countries. They began by working in restaurants. Now they own the restaurants and work them very successfully. They worked in vegetable growing. They moved into working the vegetable plantations, such as those that I know in Carnarvon in the west and Wanneroo near Perth. Now they own those market gardens. They started off mainly on the piece work system. By their diligence-their willingness to work-and their skill they have succeeded.

I would now like to cite some figures indicating the effects of migration after the Second World War, mainly from 1945 to 1973. From the United Kingdom and Ireland we had 1 1/2 million people; from Germany we had 276,000; from Greece 215,000; from Italy 410,000; from the Netherlands 156,000; and from Yugoslavia 100,000. This is just a sample of the countries that have supplied migrants to us. In 1947 fewer than 3 per cent of Australians were of non-Anglo-Saxon origin, but by 1975, 25 per cent of the population came from other than Anglo-Saxon origins. Whether those people came from the United Kingdom on a #10 migration deal or from one of the other places, we certainly owe them a vote of thanks.

Whether we believe it or not, Australia is still a land of opportunities. I have told the Senate what the latest group of migrants-those who have come to Australia since the Vietnam war-has been able to achieve. Although our Treasurer (Mr Keating)-perhaps it was the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh)-has told us that we are heading down the Argentinean road, I believe that it is not too late to reverse that decline.

As I said a little earlier, I know from the travelling that I have done how much of a lucky country Australia still is. We consider that we have an unemployment problem. Let me give the Senate an example of the unemployment situation overseas. When I was in Italy last year I talked to a young lady of about 20 years of age who had just graduated as a school teacher. I said, `Congratulations on having graduated. When do you start work?'. She told me that there was absolutely no chance of her getting work for four years. She also said that to have a chance at the end of four years of getting a job as a school teacher she would have to attend teachers training college four hours a week. These colleges are set up pretty well in that if students happen to get a temporary job during the week they can attend classes on a Saturday. I said to her, `What are you doing in the meantime?'. She said, `Well, I have gone through every restaurant looking for a washing-up job because I cannot get anything else'. This was in a town of 30,000 people. She told me that she was unsuccessful. There is no dole or unemployment benefit paid there.

Australia provides an unemployment benefit and we have a choice of working in different jobs. The opportunities for work are still available. Maybe people cannot get jobs exactly where they want to work but if they are happy to travel around our vast country they will find jobs more easily.

I will now move to the 1980s and tell the Senate what success can mean. I want to speak about the children of the migrants who have come to this country from Vietnam. As an example, I refer to what has happened in the senior high school at Swanbourne in Western Australia. Swanbourne is noted for its army base and army land and also for its beautiful beaches. At one time the senior high school at Swanbourne did not have, to put it plainly, a very high academic standard or a high standard of behaviour. There were a lot of problems at that school. Swanbourne also has a migrant centre which now accommodates Vietnamese children but which accommodated other migrants previously. Vietnamese children are now attending the senior high school. The standard of the school has risen to such an extent that students are now picking up more than half of the general exhibitions and units exhibitions in the tertiary entrance examinations in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite right.

—Although I disagreed with what Senator Jenkins said yesterday, she agrees with what I have just said. Those results show what hard work can do. I think a lot of Australians could return to the principle of hard work. Vietnamese students have not only achieved a high standard at the Swanbourne senior high school, but are also among the top students in the entrance quotas of the medicine and engineering faculties of the University of Western Australia and the colleges of advanced education. They have shown what can be achieved in Australia if we are willing to do some hard work.

SPEECH.PARA: We certainly have to look after and encourage migration. The rise in the birth rate, or the natural increase in population, seems to have ceased. In fact, the birth rate may be declining. We have to encourage a growth in population in the future with a balanced policy of migration.

I have been off the point for quite a long time, but I thought that we should recognise how migration has helped Australia over the years. Returning to the Bill, I want to refer mainly to the $5 fee that is to be imposed on residents returning to Australia and on migrants coming to Australia. I am totally agin the idea. Firstly, if the Government insists on introducing this fee for the privilege of coming into this country-and how I value my citizenship of this country!-the fee of $5 is an insult. It is an insult to impose such a fee, and if we have to have it, it is an insult for it to be as low as $5. Honourable senators can take that whichever way they want.

TALK.START.PARA: —Should it be $100?

—Senator Schacht, I am not advocating that it should be $100. But I consider that it is an insult both ways. It is the Government's Bill, and the Government can work it out. I will leave honourable senators with a final thought. They probably know the rules and privileges of life membership of a club. I am a life member of one society in Western Australia, and there are probably senators in this chamber who are life members of others. One of the principal privileges of being a life member of a society is that we can go to that society at any time, whether invited or not, at no charge. I consider this Bill to be a great insult to myself and to others holding Australian citizenship. If they have left this country and are asked to pay $5 to re-enter it, that is totally against the principles of life membership.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing the Migration Amendment Bill 1987. It was not my intention, until a short while ago, to speak to this legislation, but it just came to me that today is a very important day, not only in my life and my family's life but also in the life of Australia, because today is the eighteenth anniversary of my and my family's arrival in this country as migrants. The fifth of November is a very important day particularly in European parts of the world. It is celebrated in Britain particularly as Guy Fawkes Day. Guy Fawkes is reputed to have been the only person ever to enter Parliament with honest intentions-but I assure the Senate that that does not apply to me.
—Your intentions are dishonest?

—Well, I wonder. I am going to see the Governor-General this afternoon, and being what I am and where I am from, things can be tempting from time to time. But enough of that. Let us get on with the Migration Amendment Bill 1987.
—What have you got to say about the Scrutiny of Bills report?
—I am not going to say a great deal about the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills report, Senator Reid. I will leave that to the people who are more informed about it than I am.
—Be careful.
—I am always careful, Senator Reynolds. That report will be addressed by the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) in her reply.
—Senator McKiernan, please proceed with the Bill.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. That was an important question from Senator Reid, however, and it was worth while answering the interjection, because the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has raised some very important matters that need to be addressed in this Bill. Migration is a subject that is of extreme importance to this country. It is a nation founded on migration. The honourable senator from Western Australia, Senator Panizza, went through some figures relating to the number of people who have come from other parts of the world to settle in this great land. I was not quick enough to copy down each and every one of the figures Senator Panizza mentioned. Undoubtedly, all of us in this chamber and people outside in the community are aware of how multicultural this society is and how many different nationalities and races of people have come here and are making outstanding contributions in many respects to the welfare of this nation and its people. Indeed, Senator Panizza in his maiden speech in this place a short while ago mentioned that he too was of European extraction-I believe it was Italian. The Italians are a people who have made an outstanding contribution to this country, particularly in Western Australia, the State which both Senator Panizza and I represent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Migration Amendment Bill is controversial in a number of areas, not the least of which is the proposed $5 re-entry fee. It might be noteworthy to mention the number of movements of people into this country each year. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) in the other place alluded to this in some detail in his reply to the debate on the Bill. Last year 2.9 million visitors came to Australia. One can imagine the enormous task of processing those people through our airports into this country.

Even though we are talking about a controversial matter, I think that now is the time to congratulate those people who work at our international points of entry. Like Senator Pa-nizza-unlike some other honourable senators, I am not going to continue the attack on Senator Crichton-Browne or Senator Hill-I am not a great international traveller, but I did have the good fortune to visit Britain and Ireland earlier this year. Although I can make a comparison only between the re-entry points at Perth and London I can say that our clearances in Australia were speedier and more courteous than we experienced in London.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you come in by charter?

—No, we did not. We came in on a scheduled Qantas Airways Ltd flight. Our processing was very rapid, considering the number of people on the plane. However, when we arrived in London we were in a queue for an hour and a half just to get processed through immigration. I think that if we could adopt a charge to help people get through Customs a little easier, those 2.9 million people coming to our shores would be more than happy to pay $5 or even $10. I do not think that we would want to charge as much as Senator Panizza suggested. I think that those visitors would pay that fee quite willingly if it would expedite the re-entry processes.

SPEECH.PARA: The $5 fee is a controversial issue. However, it costs this Government and, in turn, the people of Australia quite a deal of money to employ the people to do the processing for us at the re-entry points. I instance the period of the Ame-rica's Cup in Western Australia in the latter part of last year and earlier this year when there was a glut of visitors. The airport services and the people who staff those services were stretched to the extreme facilitating the entry of visitors and making those visitors to our great nation feel at home right from the very beginning. I think it is important that international tourists and visitors are not messed around too much when they come in.

The Government has had consultations with the airline industry with regard to the collection of the $5 fee. People will not actually have to have $5 in their hot little hands when they arrive at the airport. The airline companies will collect that fee with the issuing of the ticket which will be easier than the visitors having to have $5 in their hands at the time of entry.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might not have any Australian dollars left.

—Yes, if people spend like my wife and I do, they may not have any money left when they get back. Certainly my wife and I did have some difficulties when we arrived back in Australia. We did not have any foreign currency to give to the kids to show them what the money is like in other places. It is an advantage that the airline companies will collect the fee for us.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area of controversy, mentioned by a previous speaker, has been the increase in the cost of appealing against a migration rejection. It is interesting to note the number of appeals that go before the immigration review panels. Such appeals have not just increased at a steady rate; the number of people who are making application to come here and who, for one reason or another, have had their applications rejected, has actually exploded out of all proportion. Previously, the number of appeals was about 6,000. However, over the past 18 months those 6,000 appeals have escalated to 26,000. Of course, that has created a huge backlog. I suppose than an increase in the charge for making appeals may disadvantage some people. However, I am sure that those people who are dedicated and who have a will to come to this country will find the additional few dollars they need for the appeal. There is a long list of people on the appeals list. However, the Government has taken steps to ensure that that list will be shortened and that people will not have an unduly long waiting time in order to get their appeal heard. We have increased the number of people on the review panels from 32 to 157. In turn that should-and, indeed, it is doing so at the moment-expedite the hearing of those appeals.

The Bill also serves as a revenue raiser in a number of other areas. We have increased from $2,000 to $3,000 the penalty for breach of section 11c of the Migration Act dealing with airlines or shipping companies bringing people into this country without documentation. Hopefully, that will inhibit those companies in allowing people to come in without the necessary documentation and ensure that checks and rechecks of the people purchasing tickets will be made with a greater degree of diligence. We do not have a tremendous number of problems in this are, however.

The Bill also amends a number of other areas. It requires that people requesting visas and entry permits make their requests in writing, in a form approved by the Minister. Of course, that request has to be accompanied by the prescribed fee. Senator Panizza would agree with that change. It is logical that that should be in such a shape and form.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I wasn't grinning about that. I was thinking of something else.

—I am sorry, I could not hear Senator Panizza because I was talking. Further, the Bill establishes an infringement notice scheme as an alternative to prosecution for bringing passengers to Australia without documentation. That is in addition to what I said earlier about the increase in penalty. I have talked about the clearance charge in some detail. That charge will continue to be controversial. It is something that needs to be talked through within the community. Certainly, the Government has to get its act together in telling people what this is about.

SPEECH.PARA: A matter raised by Senator Bishop, who spoke earlier, was the retrospectivity of the Bill's application. Retrospectivity has been before us regarding a number of matters, particularly taxation. It is something that we logically have to introduce. If one makes changes in the area of migration one has to make decisions and they have to come into effect, in most instances, when those decisions are announced, otherwise people will be skirting around the corners on them.

I have mentioned the main points of the Bill. The Minister and his Department will be busy. It is reputed that for every 10 people who want to come to Australia only one person is accepted. So quality migrants are coming here, working and contributing to our nation, a nation that was built on migration from all over the world, as Senator Panizza has said. We will continue to accept migrants but, unfortunately, we cannot take everybody who wants to come here. If we took the well over one million applicants who apply each year the resources of our nation would be stretched to their limit in terms of the infrastructure we have to supply to them. We have to provide housing, transportation, roads, schools and so on. At the moment we could not take the number of people who are applying to come here.

I think it is probably enough for me to say on this very exciting day in my life-we have been in this country only 18 years to the day-that we have enjoyed our time here and we will continue to enjoy the next 18 years. I am pleased that in my present position of serving the people of Australia in the national Parliament I can in some way repay the nation and its people for what they have done for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators for their contribution in debating the Migration Amendment Bill 1987. There have been some very positive contributions during the debate and, although it is clear that a number of concerns have been raised by members of the Opposition both yesterday and this morning, generally speaking it was the intention of the Opposition to accept the Bill-Senator Chaney and Senator Short said this in their opening remarks-as it is a Budget measure. There have probably been three major points of criticism and disagreement. I will refer to each of those matters. Some aspects that will be raised will be debated further at the committee stage of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The major criticism that a number of honourable senators have raised is to call the fee a tax. There has been a great deal of confusion on the part of Opposition senators because in one breath they criticised and said that it is not really a fee, it is a tax, but in the next breath they referred to the fee as a fee, which, of course, it is. I emphasise the difference between a tax and a fee. A tax is to raise money for the purpose of government and it does not necessarily relate to the provision of any specific service, whereas a fee is imposed in respect of a service provided to the person on whom the fee is imposed. It is imposed as a means of full or partial cost recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean that there is a difference between a departure tax and an arrival tax? What is the difference?

—I will come to the departure tax later but, of course, it was a tax-raising measure by the previous Government. If the amount recovered does not bear a reasonable relation to the actual costs involved of providing the service, the fee would be a tax. What service is provided by a departure tax? It is quite obvious. Costs in relation to the provision of the immigration clearance function exceed expected income from the fee. It is important to note that Senator Short talked a great deal about broken promises. This measure is not a tax. I would have thought that the Opposition was keen on the user pays principle and that is what this measure is. Those who cannot afford overseas holidays do not pay for those who can.

SPEECH.PARA: Tourists who come to Australia could easily afford a $5 fee. If they could not afford $5 to come into Australia I am not quite sure what their budget arrangements would be for their plans when visiting this country. If paying $5 is to be such a deterrent to tourists coming to Australia, it is quite obvious that they should not be considering a holiday in this country. This also applies to returning Australians.

Let us look at who is able to afford a holiday overseas. As Senator McKiernan said, it is very nice if one can afford an overseas holiday. Is it too much to ask people to pay $5 to come back into Australia? Many Australians cannot afford overseas holidays. Frankly, I think it is quite pathetic that Opposition senators say that this $5 fee is unacceptable. Senator Panizza called it an insult and he then said if we have to have this fee it might as well be raised to a higher level. All I can say is that Senator Panizza would probably be very popular with Senator Stone but I do not know how popular he would be with other members of the Opposition who have already indicated that they do not accept the $5 charge.

The Opposition amendment, which was moved by Senator Short, refers to the charge as a fee, not a tax. I suggest that honourable senators on the other side of this chamber make up their minds. Are they arguing that it is a tax, in which case they should be consistent? Otherwise, they should accept what the Government has indicated, that is, that this amount is a fee for a service that is provided.

Earlier in the debate Senator Short referred to the $20 that one must pay to leave the country. The $20 fee that the Fraser Government imposed is 400 per cent as obnoxious as the $5 that must be paid to re-enter Australia. I can understand the views that have been expressed by the tourist industry and the airline industry. They do not like the idea of collecting a $5 fee for the services we provide. Nevertheless, I am sure they will learn to live with it. I believe Senator Jenkins raised a question that the airline industry was not consulted. She acknowledged the fact that as the fee was a Budget measure of course it could not be floated with the airline industry before Budget night. But on Budget night 27 industry representatives met with Government officials so the Government did everything possible, under the necessary constraints of a budgetary measure, to inform and to consult with the industry, and that consultation is ongoing.

In the case of immigration and ethnic affairs, certain services must be delivered and they are of the utmost importance as many honourable senators have acknowledged. If we make a decision about the imposition of a clearance fee for people to re-enter the country, to cover some expenditure that we would like to persuade Cabinet colleagues ought to be spent in the area of settlement services or English classes, that shows the position the Government prefers to take. Which would the Opposition prefer? To have this fee for service or to take away from the very important services that are provided to migrants in our community? It is a sensible way to go about the business of government and the business of protecting migrants who come to this country. It is true that, because of the enormous influx of visitors to Australia, the Government has been investing very heavily in the immigration clearance areas of airports. Of the 2.9 million visitors to Australia last year, 45,000 were referred to immigration officials. It does not take very much imagination to appreciate just what work load that puts on the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Some 400 of those were not even allowed to enter, and about 100 were detained.

Another part of the legislation imposes on the spot fines for airlines, some of which do not take much notice of whether people have the proper documentation for landing. Again, this is a sensible measure. Nobody likes to impose on the spot fines. It is something that any responsible government has to introduce when it looks at the figures of people coming into this country and the additional work load that this is creating. The airlines have to be responsible and have to check out visa requirements. People may not recognise the difficulties that can arise in this regard. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Young, in his speech in the other place, referred to a conversation he had had with someone from the Canadian Embassy in Bangkok. Canada is now dealing with 20,000 people who arrived illegally this year, and there will be a special session of parliament to discuss and deal with this enormous problem. In terms of resources, obviously the Government must make up its mind whether it can legitimately recoup some of the costs of the services that it provides.

Senator Panizza referred to the $5 fee as being the only such fee in the world, and said that he had never experienced it before. All I can say is that Senator Panizza has not been a visitor to the United States recently, because the $5 fee is exactly the same as the fee that is paid in the United States. Using the resources of manpower and the very sophisticated computer programs which the Immigration Department now has in place we can try to identify who is and who is not legitimately entitled to enter this country. We need that additional financial revenue. We have invested very heavily in this area, and we have to make up our minds whether it is legitimate to try to recoup some of the costs. In this case, we say that we can justify the $5 immigration clearance fee. We have told the airlines that they can make up their own minds about how they collect it, but it will be up to them. Every few months we expect the airlines to pay the fee. Obviously, I do not expect the airlines to be overjoyed at this, but it is a very necessary measure, as I think that I have shown.

The next criticism, which came from several speakers, was the question of government by regulation or by Press release, as Senator Bishop called it. Clause 9 (a) of the Migration Amendment Bill provides for the making of regulations to prescribe the categories of reconsiderable decisions; the level of the fee for requests for reconsideration; the standing requirement to make an application for reconsideration; the circumstances in which the fee will be chargeable or refundable; and incidental matters such as time limits within which applications for reconsideration of reviewable decisions are made. As a number of honourable senators have acknowledged, there has been an explosion in the number of requests for review of Migration Act decisions. There has been an increasing backlog-this was raised by a number of senators in our Estimates hearings-and long delays of up to 18 months or more in some cases in deciding appeals.

TALK.START.PARA: —So now you are just going to take all those rights away from them.
—All I can say is: What suggestions does the Opposition have? How would it deal with the situation?
—What about justice for the people concerned?

—It is very nice to talk about justice, and I think that my commitment to justice would be every bit equal to that of Senator Messner, but I do not think that just talking about justice will solve the problem of those delays. Is Senator Messner seriously suggesting that, if he got up and made a speech about justice, those delays would simply disappear? We have to have practical solutions. All that Senator Messner can suggest is an ideal, which of course the Government agrees with, but we have to be able to achieve that ideal. We are achieving the ideal of justice through the measures that Minister Young has outlined. The Government had to address this problem and we are starting to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: As Minister Young said in his speech in the other place on 28 October, when winding up the second reading debate:

One must make up one's mind whether one will continue to say to everybody, `You will all be treated equally; you can appeal', or whether one should cut out some people if they do not have a certain number of points. In that case, there will be a lot of protests.
That would not be justice, Senator Messner. The Minister continued:

People will say that they are not being treated equally. One can try to deal with it in another way-which we have done-by providing extra services at great cost to the Government and try to recoup some of those expenses, which we have done by imposing the appeal fee. We will get through the appeals a lot quicker.
That, Senator Messner, is our form of justice.

There has been a large increase in the number of Immigration Review Panel members, from 32 to 157-and I cannot think of a better example of a just government recognising this problem-and a more than doubling of the staff of the Department's review function to nearly 150. There has been decentralisation of the review function to mainland States to provide a more directly accessible, faster and client-oriented service. And the legislation is the minimum of legislation that one can provide for the $240 fee for review. I think that if we are really serious about Senator Messner's comment about justice, it is obvious that in the measures that we have taken we want justice for all these people who have been waiting and who have experienced the trauma of not knowing one way or the other. We are speeding up the process, and that is the reason for the $240 fee.

The last issue relates to retrospectivity. I anticipate that we will be debating this issue in much more detail in the committee stage. I acknowledge the comments of Senator Bishop and the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which appeared only late yesterday. Before I deal with the issues that arose from that report, I would just like to make some general comments about retrospectivity, because it is very easy, when certain people move from government into opposition, for them to have fairly short memories. It is not uncommon that legislation based on Budget measures be retrospective to the date of announcement. This technical form of so-called retrospectivity was used extensively by the Opposition when in government. For example, the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Act 1981 was assented to on 2 December 1981 but was deemed to come into operation on 1 September 1981. Secondly, the Television Stations Licence Fees Act 1981 was assented to on 2 December 1981 but was operative from 1 September 1981. In talking generally about retrospectivity, it is important to acknowledge that the Opposition-which can now afford to be critical-participated in retrospective legislation when it was in government, in the Fraser years.

In conclusion, I would like to refer to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I would like to read from its report where the Committee thanked the Minister for his response to a letter that it wrote last week expressing some concerns about this piece of legislation. The report states:
The Committee is happy to accept that the Immigration Clearance Fee is intended to be a fee for service-
so that clears that matter up-
and that it appears to bear a reasonable relation to the costs of the service involved.
It further states:

Equally however, the Committee believes there are not insuperable practical problems in limiting amount of such a fee to a maximum by legislation, given that a realistic maximum (based on recovery of cost) should be fixed. It is by this means that the Parliament can continue to properly scrutinise such provisions.

The retrospective operation of regulations has been mentioned by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report and was raised earlier this morning by Senator Bishop. I have referred some of those points to the Attorney-General's office for comment. I have received advice which I will read for the benefit of honourable senators, although I am sure that this aspect will be more fully debated in the committee stage. The advice reads:

The Office of the Parliamentary Counsel is not in any difficulty about the retrospective operation of any regulations, as 48.2 only applies to provisions which state the express retrospective date-that is, where the regulations go outside the power of the Act. These regulations do not state this, rather they rely on the Act which empowers retrospectivity. These regulations do not state a commencement outside the power of the Act.
Amendment agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that earlier today, accompanied by honourable senators, I waited upon the Governor-General and presented to him the Address-in-Reply to the Speech of His Excellency on the occasion of the opening of Parliament, which was agreed to on Wednesday, 28 October 1987. His Excellency was pleased to make the following reply:

INTERJECT.PARA: It will be my pleasure and duty to convey to Her Majesty the Queen the message of loyalty from the Senate to which the Address gives expression.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask him whether he is aware that, in its latest report, Syntec Economic Services Pty Ltd has strongly criticised the Government's decision to support another across-the-board wage rise at the current national wage case hearing, saying:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Government's approach to the national wage case is sending all the wrong signals-as the fall in the Australian dollar attests.
I ask the Minister whether he agrees with Syntec's conclusion that in the wake of recent events:
the Government cannot responsibly agree to carry on with existing wages policy as if nothing has happened.

Will the Government take the opportunity of tonight's meeting with the leadership of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to make it clear to the union movement that across-the-board pay rises not linked to increased productivity are off the agenda for future wages policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the broad outline of the Syntec report, which, I remind the Senate, does not predict any likely rapid economic shake-out in response to the fall in the world stock markets. However, I am aware that the Treasurer made a statement about that matter last week, as I am sure Senator Chaney will be aware. Insofar as the question relates to the publicised meeting with the Australian Council of Trade Unions later today, I am unable to make any statement about that. In his meeting with the ACTU the Minister will, of course, put forward to it whatever is considered to be the appropriate position. No doubt there will be some public announcement about it after the meeting takes place, but there will certainly not be one from me beforehand.

ANSWER.PARA: On the more general question, the Government believes that its firm fiscal policy and wage restraint have, up to now, provided an effective strategy. At the moment we are not about indulging in knee-jerk responses to events, particularly in the stock market, which have taken place in the last couple of weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question which follows the Minister's unsatisfactory reply. Why is the Australian community not entitled to know the Government's attitude to the essential wages policy which will affect the Australian economy very greatly? —Wages policy under this Government has produced a reduction of between 8 and 10 per cent in real wages in the last four years. That is almost the exact opposite of what the coalition Government produced in one year in its last year in office. Senator Chaney also in his initial question related wage increases to the question of productivity, and I omitted to answer that point of the question. Under the second tier of the current wage negotiations productivity issues have been crucial; they are an integral part of the second tier wage proposals. I understand from numerous businesses and corporations that those second tier negotiations, which in a sense were an experiment in the Australian context, have been attended with a high degree of success. I also remind Senator Chaney that whatever one might think, or he might think, of the Australian Council of Trade Unions document Australia Reconstructed--
—Whatever you might think of it.

—Whatever Senator Chaney might think, I said, it contains one very important element; That is, the recognition by the ACTU that wage movements in this country had to be considered with wage movements in countries which are trading partners. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

QUESTION.PARA: One of the most serious blows to the local economy is likely to come through the impact on private investment spending.
What are the likely consequences for the Australian economy of any significant reduction in the level of business investment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Insofar as Senator Lewis was referring to a reported comment made by me in New York about the likely consequence of the share market crash being a slow-down in investment, I did not confine my observations to Australia. Insofar as Senator Lewis asked me about the impact of a slow-down of investment in Australia, such a slow-down, if it occurred, would be detrimental to economic growth. A slightly different view of the world has been advocated or talked about by a number of business people, which is that the stock market crash will lead not only to more cautious investment but also to much greater selectivity in investments. I think that is probably likely.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, if one considers activity in the last year or so on the second board of the Australian stock exchange there is a likelihood of some reduction in investment in those sorts of stocks. But I think the consequences will be a much more selective investment in second board activity than there has been in the past. That may not be an altogether bad thing. It is a little too early to make judgments about it. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my Gallery of a parliamentary delegation from New Zealand, led by Mr K. L. Shirley, MP. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. Has he seen the article in yesterday's Melbourne Herald titled `ALP set to renege on greenie deal'? TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the reported comments of the Managing Director of Slade Consulting Group Pty Ltd that Australia's school retention rate to year 12 of 50 per cent compares poorly with that of Japan and the United States of America; that there is a lack of urgency being displayed towards our lack of skills; and that in computing we are `desperately short' of skilled personnel and are having to recruit overseas? Mr Slade specifically mentions that his firm has 300 computer jobs available in private companies and government agencies. Is there any substance to these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is some substance in the views that the participation rate through to year 12 in Australia is not yet high enough. It is also true that there are skill shortages in some areas. But there is certainly no substance in the suggestion that the Government is not responding urgently to this situation. We have been involved in this area for some years. Mr Slade may not be aware that this year we have a 50 per cent retention of students to year 12. Of course, this is a very much better outcome than the situation when we first took office in 1983 when only one-third of young people were finishing secondary school.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has already set the target of achieving a 65 per cent retention rate to the end of year 12 by the early 1990s. That is a high target, given that we have a very large technical and further education sector which many 16- to 17-year-olds choose to go into for training. So we assert that we have certainly set targets and we are certainly moving very quickly towards them.

Mr Slade should be aware, too, that the development of vocational skills is one of the main emphases of this year's Budget, which included the introduction of a new skills training program, including support for innovative training projects and skills centres where there is a significant contribution from industry; a substantial increase in the number of trainees under the Australian traineeship system; an increase of over 12 per cent in expenditure on apprenticeships, bringing the expenditure in that program to $129m with major revisions to the form of assistance as a basis for future reform of apprenticeship; the introduction of the youth training program, with expenditure of over $30m in 1987-88, and we expect that program to assist some 13,000 young people; the expansion of the adult training program to assist an estimated 13,000 adults this year; and continued support for labour adjustment programs in industries undergoing structural change, including coal mining and textiles, clothing and footwear.

It should never be forgotten that with the onset of the recession at the beginning of the 1980s, almost the first reaction of Australian industry was to contract the number of apprenticeships that it offered. What is missing now are the qualified trades people that those apprentices would have been by now. TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!
—You can make a statement later.

—Mr President, it is really extraordinary that the Opposition is not interested in the very positive and urgent steps that the Government is taking to fill skill shortages and to ensure that we will be competitive in our skills base with Japan and other countries.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SHARE MARKET CRASH: WITHDRAWAL OF MONEY FROM AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to answers which the Minister has given on several occasions to Senator Stone about the withdrawal of money from Australia since the share market crash. Is the Minister asserting that the Government cannot find out the nature of these withdrawals for about two months? If the answer is yes, why cannot the Government obtain such vital information whenever it is required? If the answer is no, why does the Government not take steps to inform itself and, if appropriate, the Parliament, of the nature of these withdrawals?

—For those who have a mind set in the 1970s, in the days of the authoritarian empire over which Senator Stone presided, with rigid exchange rates and international currency transaction controls, the volume of trading actually meant something, because, since the rate was fixed, if there was any disequilibrium, it would affect the volume of trading. When the rate is flexible the volume of trading does not necessarily mean a great deal at all. The reason why the Reserve Bank does not publish information about its smoothing and testing operations I would have thought was certainly known by Senator Stone and was even self-evident, and that is that if the Reserve Bank of Australia is itself trading in currency, it obviously does not want to tell everybody else in the market what it is doing at a particular time. There is normally a time lag of, I think, about two months between the actual activities of the bank and the time at which those activities become public knowledge. It is, I understand, in the total transactions in any day, impossible to unscramble what is going on, because currency transactions, of course, are conducted outside the Reserve Bank these days by private banks, and essentially the same transaction might be turned over several times in the day in the market, so the volume figures for a day or even a week are, first, totally impossible to unscramble, and secondly, insofar as the Reserve Bank is involved, there are very good reasons for not making public the volume of trading or prices at which the Reserve Bank is trading.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. I am certainly not aware of them if they are around. Given that I have on a number of occasions stated my support for uranium mining, I assume that if they were around, I would know of them.

ANSWER.PARA: opposing mining or any other activity in National Parks which adversely affects the prime function of the park, i.e. nature conservation.
