I would have thought that the matter would be more in the province of my colleague Mr Hand. I shall ascertain from him the progress of any discussions he has had with the Western Australian Government and notify the honourable senator as soon as I have that information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I still remain unconvinced, I am sorry, about the three mines policy on uranium mining, which I think is a concern shared by many people in the community. I take it from the Minister's answer that he does not agree with the Western Australian Ministers-
—Order! Senator Vallentine, I ask you to ask your supplementary question.

—Mr President, I want to clarify whether the Minister agrees or disagrees with David Parker's stated aim to change the three mines policy on mining uranium; whether that is by inclusion of other mines or substitution. If the Minister does not agree, I ask him what the Government is prepared to do about it.

—As I said earlier, I and the rest of the Party are bound by Party policy on that matter. I might say that that is a policy that has been oft debated and was the subject, so far as I can recall, of the only division at the National Conference. Therefore, to change that policy in any way would require a decision of the National Conference. Most importantly, I think, it would require 50 delegates out of 99 delegates to vote for the change.
—Why?

—I ask Senator Macklin what he means by `why'. Fifty votes is a majority out of 99 votes! Senator Macklin is his Party's Whip; he is supposed to be able to count. To change that policy would require 50 votes. At the moment, I think they would be pretty hard to find. Predicting national conferences is not necessarily the safest occupation in the world when one is talking of the Australian Labor Party. Personally, I would be very surprised to see that policy changed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STATUS OF WOMEN IN PUBLIC SERVICE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I draw her attention to the recent announcement of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority that certain high status jobs, such as those of principal, which do not attract enough female applicants are readvertised as the Authority's contribution to the advancement of women. Does the Minister agree that women have an equal opportunity to respond to the initial advertisements? Does the Minister endorse the ridiculous decision of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority to readvertise such positions? Does she believe that it is an action that ought to be followed by all the bodies affected by the Public Service Reform Act, the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act and the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Act? If so, how does the Minister think these bodies should decide when enough women have applied or reapplied?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to that part of Senator Vanstone's question about the decision of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority to readvertise when it does not have female applicants, I think that it is a sensible idea. I will explain why. It is not the case that women in the Australian Capital Territory teaching service have felt that they would be considered on their merits or that they would be considered equally with men if they applied for principals' jobs. It is not surprising that they have had that belief since no female principal has been appointed in the Australian Capital Territory. There was one provisional appointment of a female principal. That was challenged and the challenge was upheld. In my view, and I would think in Senator Vanstone's view, that is a reflection on the lack of a merit based system. We have a teaching service in the Australian Capital Territory which has a very high proportion of female members-a very highly educated and well-trained female teaching service-yet in all the years that the Australian Capital Territory teaching service has existed no woman has been appointed as principal. The woman who was initially appointed as principal lost that appointment on appeal.

ANSWER.PARA: In that atmosphere I do not think that it is surprising that many women who would like to think of their careers as leading to a principal's position have not applied because they have felt discouraged by the history of the Australian Capital Territory in relation to the appointment of principals. In those circumstances I think that it is a sensible and responsible course of action for the Authority to remind women that now, under more enlightened leadership, they are entitled to apply and that they will be considered on their merits. I do not regard that as negative discrimination, as a waste of money or any of those things. I hope that when the Authority readvertises it gets high quality, female candidates applying. I would like to see female principals appointed on the basis of merit to positions of leadership in the Australian Capital Territory schools system. While we continue to have a situation whereby only men are in leadership positions in our schools it is very difficult to encourage girls to believe that they should consider themselves equal in all matters and to aspire, in the same way that male students aspire, to careers of their choice.

There is no administrative or legal connection between the way in which the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority is implementing its equal employment opportunity (EEO) policies and the legislation which covers the Commonwealth Public Service and Commonwealth statutory authorities. The way in which those bodies are to proceed to implement EEO provisions is set out in various pieces of legislation. It may well be that when they decide to advertise outside the Service they may decide to make it very clear in their advertisements that women are entitled to apply. The legislative provisions for the Commonwealth Public Service and Commonwealth statutory bodies are fairly clear. They have been the subject of debate in this place and they are different from the way in which the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority has decided to pursue its policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are silent on re- advertising, aren't they?

—There would be no obstacle in a case where a Public Service position was advertised outside the Service-as I recall, that does not happen in every case-to making it clear in that advertisement that women were able to apply. There would be no obstacle to re-advertising if the range of candidates was regarded as being too narrow and not giving the employer an adequate choice.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am not clear from the Minister's answer whether she is saying that because the legislation affecting the Australian Capital Territory is different the question does not arise in other cases. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STATUS OF WOMEN IN PUBLIC SERVICE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, and follows that asked by Senator Vanstone, which touched on the policy of the Government to increase the percentage of women in high status occupations in the Australian Public Service. Is the Minister aware, as outlined in the Women's Budget Statement, which I believe the Minister herself gave in this place, that the percentage of women in keyboard areas has increased, rather than decreased? Notwithstanding the existence of equal opportunity programs, is the Government concerned about this, and what does the Government intend to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly aware of the situation described by the honourable senator in his question. I am certainly concerned about it, and the Government is concerned about it. That is why we have embarked on a series of programs arising from a package of legislation that has been passing through this place over the last couple of years. If there were no problem, we would not need the legislation and the programs, but there is a problem. The problem referred to in the honourable senator's question goes not only to lack of encouragement to women to aspire to senior positions but to the sex segregation of the labour force in Australia. It is the case that Australia has the most sex segregated labour market of any country in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. We suffer huge efficiency and skills losses because of that.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the effects of affirmative action legislation and similar policies will be to open up a range of occupations to men and women so that, one would hope, after some years of having these programs in place, there would be many more males in keyboard occupations; at the same time, we would see females going into the technical and skilled occupations that they are not currently in. It is a question of broadening the base of female employment, as well as providing opportunities for women to move into more senior positions. We are tackling both these problems through a range of policies and through legislation but, of course, we do not expect that, such a short time after the legislation has been enacted, we will have solved the problems. I hope and expect that next year's Women's Budget Statement will contain a more encouraging picture.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the comments just made by the Minister, I would like her to account for certain factors. Why is it that, in the keyboard area, the percentages in the very statement that she gave to the Senate have got worse rather than better? In that statement, women comprised 97 per cent of the keyboard operators. They now comprise 98.3 per cent. Whereas the participation of women over the three-year period from 1984 to 1986 improved from 55 per cent to 57 per cent, overall, the position of women has got far worse. I would like Senator Ryan to comment on and account for this.

—If Senator Tambling had paid attention to some of the debates around these issues that have ensued in this place, he would appreciate that keyboard jobs are not sought after by men. This is because they do not pay particularly well, do not carry great status and do not usually lead to an advanced career structure. The Government cannot make men become keyboard operators in the Public Service. What we are trying to do is open up more opportunities for women so that they will see that they have options other than keyboard operating, and will have the confidence to seek those. We cannot determine the choice that people make in employment and clearly men, now as ever, will go for the higher paid, more prestigious jobs.

—Order! I will allow the question. I remind the Minister not to give a legal opinion, and to deal with only that part of the question that dealt with electoral matters under his jurisdiction.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Aulich went on to ask what was the position under the Commonwealth Act. This does not require a legal opinion but just a recitation of facts. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The weighting for health, hospital and medical services in the CPI is just over 2 per cent. The part of the index relating to medical services covers a much broader range of services than the standard consultation. But if one assumes that charges for all services are raised commensurately with the standard consultation the theoretical CPI effect can be approximated. Medical services are treated in the CPI net of Medicare and health fund benefits. TALK.START.PARA: —Surely not.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and Transport. Is it true, as continues to be claimed by the Opposition, that the Government has rigged a flight monopoly to Christmas Island for Ansett-TNT?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Suggestions to this effect continue to appear in the Press; for example, in the Canberra Times on a couple of occasions this week and again this morning in the Sydney Morning Herald. They are stimulated by two things: firstly, alleged reports of the views on this subject of the Christmas Island developer Mr Woodmore; and, secondly, of course, the campaign of innuendo which continues to be waged by the honourable member for Bruce, based on the premise that one company, Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd (TNT), has purchased or has the option on 72 British Aerospace 146s-the entire production run for the next five or so years-a point which he made in these terms in the House of Representatives on 27 October and which has inspired most of this debate subsequently.

ANSWER.PARA: I am able to advise the Senate that neither of the two bases which have sustained this campaign has any foundation whatsoever. In the first place, I table for the scrutiny of anyone who is interested and will read into the record a fax memo received today in my Department from Mr Frank Woodmore of Christmas Island Resort Pty Ltd which is in the following terms:

Further to yesterday's telecom, I am concerned that the media has distorted a statement I made in relation to the approval we hold for Christmas Island Aerodrome. Apparently, yesterday's Canberra Times quotes me as stating ``that a prima facie case exists for believing that we were forced into bed with Ansett''.

I actually used these words but they have been quoted completely out of context. When the journalist asked whether I ``had been forced into bed'' with Ansett, I asked how he gained such an impression. He quoted from a statement made in the Lower House by Ken Aldred. Having read Mr Aldred's speech, I responded as follows:

``I have read Mr Aldred's speech, which he kindly copied to me. Certainly on the basis of what he has said one could gain the impression that a prima facie case exists for believing that we were forced into bed with Ansett. However, that is not the case. We offered Ansett the opportunity to participate and they declined-unless we were prepared to underwrite their flight service . . .

``The nomination of a BAe146 was made for valid technical reasons. It has been used as a benchmark so that all parties clearly understood the level to which the Airport would initially be developed'' . . .

I also advised that if other species of aircraft were able to meet the relevant requirements, we would expect approval in the normal way. We had suggested F28 and other aircraft from the north, where the over water regulation did not pose a problem.

When asked whether we felt ``pressured'' by the Department I was able to respond in a positive manner and advised the journalist that we had an excellent working relationship with the Department-as evidenced by the recent prompt attention to our request regarding an air service from Jakarta.
Unfortunately the good news was not reported.
Please feel free to use the foregoing comments to refute any media representation to the contrary.
Best regards,
F. P. Woodmore.

That, I think, disposes of that part of the allegation. As I said, this document is tabled for anyone who cares to scrutinise it. Secondly, the nub of the remainder of the allegation has been that TNT has some sort of monopoly on the entire production of BAe146s. Let me just make absolutely clear for the record that this is not so. Of the 75 BAe146 aircraft that have already been delivered out of production up to July 1987, just two have been delivered to Ansett WA and one to TNT Aviation in Europe. Three out of 75 hardly supports any existing monopoly. As to the claim that TNT has the entire production run of BAe146s for the next five years, the facts are: TNT has a commitment to take all freighter versions of the BAe146 in that period; these aircraft are expected to comprise only about 30 per cent of the total production; and all passenger versions of the BAe146 are excluded from the agreement.

The disturbing aspect of this matter is that all of these facts about the BAe146s have been brought to the attention of the honourable member for Bruce, and he knows that his claims are baseless. I table also a letter, a copy of which I have just received, from the Regional Executive of British Aerospace Australia Ltd, which was sent to Mr Aldred on 29 October. I will not waste time by quoting it, but it is in exactly the same sorts of terms as those that I have just indicated. It makes it clear that the big-door freight versions of the BAe146 are only 30 per cent of the total production and that all passenger versions of the BAe146 are totally excluded from the TNT agreement. It makes it absolutely clear for the record what I have made clear already in answering questions in this place on 29 October and what Mr Duncan has made clear on several occasions subsequently; namely, that there is no foundation whatsoever for the campaign of sneaky, pimp-like innuendo that has been perpetrated once again, as so often before, by the honourable member for Bruce. His behaviour on this matter, as so often in the past, justifies every conceivable imputation that can possibly be made against him and it is only appropriate that there should be an apology.

Senator Vanstone asked whether the Government through the Department of Social Security accepted sexual stereotyping in the determination of de facto relationships for pension purposes.
A de facto relationship exists where two people live together on a bona fide domestic basis as husband and wife.

To do this, the Department of Social Security has adopted criteria established by the Federal Court in the case of Lamb and followed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. These are designed to illustrate the nature of inter-personal relationship and include such factors as:
Dwelling under the same roof
Permanence
Exclusiveness
Sexual intercourse
Mutual society and protection
The existence of a household
The way in which the relationship is presented by the parties to the outside world
Financial support
The nurture and support of children of the relationship
Relationships within the household and whether those relationship indicate a family unit.
In relation to the last point-consideration is given on whether or not house duties are shared as in the case of de jure marriages.

While the statement to which Senator Vanstone referred indicates one particular mode of sharing domestic responsibilities-the `traditional' one referred to by the AAT in Tang-other modes of sharing domestic chores exist and are equally valid. Officers of the Department, in considering this aspect, attempt to assess whether or not there is a sharing of domestic chores similar to that in a marriage, whether the sharing be on a traditional basis or otherwise.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL YEAR OF SHELTER FOR THE HOMELESS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement on the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Mr President, as we reach the end of this year and our Parliamentary deliberations draw to conclusion, I will take this opportunity to inform honourable senators about Australia's involvement in the 1987 International Year of Shelter for the Homeless.
1987 has been a year in which the Australian community has been made aware of housing issues and encouraged to consider ways to improve our housing programs.
It has also been a year in which both government and non-government sectors have evaluated Australia's housing programs.

This Government did not need an International Year to ensure that housing remained a priority on its agenda but this International Year has provided a unique opportunity to re-examine housing problems and housing assistance, an opportunity we were pleased to take.
United Nations
I believe it would be appropriate, before I discuss Australia's contribution to the International Year, or IYSH, to talk about the origins and the international context of the Year.

The conditions of human settlements throughout the world are deteriorating. Despite considerable efforts by governments, and the poor themselves, the United Nations estimate that the number of people living in poverty continues to grow steadily-and now totals around one and a quarter billion or a quarter of the earth's population. Other statistics are equally horrifying. It has been estimated that 100 million have no shelter at all; in developing countries, half of the population, on average, live in slums and squatter settlements.

On the international scene, the problems are steadily worsening and the overall situation deteriorating. The UN predicts that within the next 10 years the urban population of developing countries will nearly double.
The International Year of Shelter for the Homeless grew out of the realization of the need to address these problems.

The UN General Assembly at its 37th session in 1982, designated 1987 as the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless. Between 1984 and 1987 the UN Centre for Human Settlements or HABITAT, the lead agency for the Year, has encouraged governments, agencies, intergovernmental and non-governmental groups to assess the degree of homelessness and the extent of inadequate shelter and basic infrastructure. The aim then is to support projects and activities which could help provide shelter to the poor and disadvantaged. Governments have been urged to adopt, by the end of 1987, plans to help all their poor and disadvantaged to obtain a home by the year 2000.
IYSH in Australia
Unlike developing countries, Australia already has a range of policies and special purpose assistance programs to alleviate housing problems.

The Federal Government makes available some $2 billion a year on housing and related programs. It is under these that ``bricks and mortar'' solutions for Australia's homeless and inadequately housed are funded. In total around $3 billion a year is spent on housing and related assistance programs in Australia.
IYSH Aims
Against this background the aims of IYSH, are to:

1. Improve the effectiveness of the current range of Federal and State housing programs and ensure that Australia's overseas aid programs are addressing some of the housing related problems in nearby countries;
2. Increase the contribution of governments and the private and community sectors towards assisting the homeless and inadequately housed; and
3. Encourage innovation and equity in the use of existing housing, and future additions to the housing stock and the financing of support mechanisms that are necessary for providing low cost housing.
These aims have also been adopted by State Governments.
IYSH Program in Australia

In agreeing to participate in IYSH, the Australian Government was mindful of the United Nations intention that IYSH activities should involve, to the fullest extent possible, non-government as well as government organisations.

To assist in planning and implementation the Government appointed Bishop Peter Hollingworth, Executive Director of the Brotherhood of St Laurence, as the Chairperson of the IYSH National Committee of Non-Government Organisations.
Major non-governmental organisations, concerned with housing such as financial institutions, industry bodies, community groups and unions were also appointed to the committee.
Separately State and Territories were requested to initiate their Governments activities.

Australia and many other countries commenced these activities at least two years ago. In 1985 and 1986, housing projects were selected, documented and evaluated, so that information and experience gained from them could be publicised this year.
Expenditure

The Federal Government will spend approximately $1.4m on IYSH activities. The great bulk of these funds, is for IYSH Projects. The remainder is being spent on a report by the Non-Government Committee on future housing policies and on providing information on IYSH activities and programs.
I would now like to outline activity under the plan for IYSH in more detail.
Needs Assessment

Much of the needs assessment phase of IYSH was undertaken prior to 1987. A major background document for the international year is the ``Study into Homelessness and Inadequate Housing'' published by the Federal Government in 1985.
Projects

In order to encourage non-government input and to gather independent evaluations of our current housing and related assistance programs, over fifty IYSH projects were funded by the Federal Government around Australia. These projects obtain consumers' views on the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, document of innovative housing projects such as the First Fremantle Housing Collective, an IYSH Schools' Kit, and research into inadequate housing on Thursday Island.
Major conferences such as the Second National Women's Housing Conference and the World Planning and Housing Congress were also supported to assist dissemination of information on housing issues.

Many of these projects have been undertaken by non-government organisations such as Aboriginal communities, community and welfare organisations, teachers, architects and women's organisations. They include the documentation and evaluation of innovative housing schemes, research and conferences.
Evaluation of Housing Programs

Many of the projects funded related to the first aim for IYSH-the improvement of the effectiveness of Australia's housing and related assistance programs. Major reviews have been undertaken by governments to this end. The Triennial Evaluation of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement has resulted in amendments to the Housing Assistance Act being introduced in the Parliament. Reviews of the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program Review and the Local Government and Community Housing Program are currently in progress.
Priorities for the Future

The United Nations objective for IYSH is to develop strategies and policies to alleviate housing poverty between now and the year 2000. Developments in Australia will contribute to this through the completion of a Report by the IYSH National Committee of Non-Government Organisations to the Federal Government with recommendations on future housing strategies and policies.

The first part of this process is under way, and a report on key issues will be made available for public comment in December. Consultations with a wide range of community and industry groups will be held in capital cities and major regional centres in February 1988 to discuss the report openly.

The views expressed in these consultations, together with the Non-Government Committee's views and recommendations will form a Response Report to the key issues. Both reports will be forwarded to the Federal Government for consideration in May 1988. These findings will be taken into account in the determination of future strategies and policy.
Information Dissemination

To have an effective International Year, it is necessary to tell people about its objectives, and the issues and problems being tackled. Community announcements on radio and television have been made by myself and Bishop Hollingworth and IYSH Kits have been distributed to encourage public participation in the program. Videos and other forms of information such as brochures, posters and photographic exhibitions have been developed and distributed widely.
States and Territories
The States and Territories in Australia have implemented their own programs of IYSH activities with a total of 90 IYSH projects under way.
Outcome

The outcome of IYSH in Australia will include the assessment of housing needs, release of IYSH project documentation, evaluation of current housing and related assistance programs, a report to the Federal Government on future directions for housing in Australia and distribution of information on housing issues and the IYSH program. A report will also be forwarded by the Australian Government to the United Nations on IYSH activities in Australia.

Further initiatives have already been taken. As a result of the recent amalgamation of Federal Departments, the Department of Community Services and Health now comprises both housing and related assistance programs such as aged persons services and supported accommodation. This will ensure far more efficient co-ordination of programs and will enable us to better assist the homeless and inadequately housed. It is fitting that this important step was taken in the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless.
Federal Government's Approach to IYSH

The approach we have adopted for IYSH is different from other international years. A program was developed that focused on improving our existing policies and programs and examining innovation solutions to housing problems, rather than maximum publicity.

We did not decide on this approach because our record in housing is something to hide. Quite the contrary, our record is outstanding. The current major programs to assist homeless persons-the Crisis Accommodation Program and the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program were both introduced by this Government. Funds made available by this Government this year for public housing exceed $1 billion.

As well, the First Home Owners Scheme is widely hailed by housing industry groups. Indeed the ethos of home ownership in Australia has been a major thrust of housing policies of successive Governments and this has created a housing climate within which direct assistance to people with a housing need can be provided.

Given our commitment to housing, we believed that there were more long term benefits to be gained from using the IYSH budget to review current housing efforts and ensure that levels of funding for housing are used efficiently and effectively in addressing Australia's housing needs.
Conclusion

I would like to finish by paying tribute to the non-government and community sectors and to the State Governments for their major contribution to IYSH. Without the effort of Bishop Peter Hollingworth and the other Non-Government Committee members, we would not have been able to achieve so much. I urge all members of the community and the Parliament to consider the report that will be published in December and to contribute to community consultation.

A range of activities have been planned across Australia for National IYSH Week to be held from 8 to 15 November. These include the International Symposium on Self Help Housing in Melbourne and Sydney, housing forums focusing on de-institutionalisation and community housing, and the launching of IYSH education kits on housing issues. The week will provide a focus for attention on the Year's activities.

To conclude, Mr President, the success of the IYSH program in Australia is not something we can gauge now or even in the near future. It is in the next 20 years that we can expect our efforts to bear fruit.

We have made a start. We have set in place a process for the examination of housing policies and programs which combines the efforts of community groups, financial and business institutions and all levels of Government. With this continuing interest and contribution from non-government and community sectors, and governments, the Australian community as a whole can develop more effective solutions to problems of homelessness and inadequate housing in our country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was under some doubts as to whether to give the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) leave to incorporate the statement, because I believe it would have been a severe embarrassment for her to have had to read it to this chamber. It is such a totally empty statement, empty of any content at all, and it represents further cynicism on the part of this Government on an issue on which, in opposition, it would have been loud in its complaints at a lack of action from our side of politics. When we can now look at the situation of the homeless after four years, we see a substantial deterioration of their position under this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an utterly cynical and utterly empty statement, which chronicles the fact that the Government has achieved absolutely nothing for the homeless, and indeed has exacerbated their situation. What we find in this statement, which is given towards the end of the parliamentary year and which is expressed as being given at the time when we reach the end of this International Year of Shelter for the Homeless, is that the Government claims to have made a start, and to have set in place a process for the examination of housing policies and programs-and that is all that has happened. What is totally absent from this statement is any attempt to measure the extent of homelessness in this country, and any attempt to suggest that the Government has in any effective way come to grips with the problems of homelessness in this country.

We can look at it from a whole series of points of view, whether from the point of view of those who are genuinely homeless, in the sense of having no shelter over their head, or from the point of view of those who are ill housed or housed in very expensive accommodation and who are seeking relief through the public housing lists or assistance with the purchase of a house. It does not matter which way we look at it: the record of this Government is a record of total failure. For it to put this statement forward as a record of some sort of achievement in the Year of the Homeless is pathetic.

This is a year in which the Government has cut $468m off its public housing programs. That may well have been an appropriate action to take, but that cut represents the total failure of the Government's programs to this point, which have involved the very considerable expenditure of additional public money, to absolutely no effect-indeed, to a negative effect. When this Government came to office there were 110,000 people on the public housing list, and that was regarded as something of a disgrace. One hundred and ten thousand Australian individuals and families were lined up waiting for public housing from the various State housing authorities.

This Government, the Labor Government, promptly greatly increased public expenditure. It nearly doubled public expenditure, as I recollect it, in its first Budget. It set off down a path which has been destructive instead of constructive, because we find today, 4 1/2 years and moving on for five years after this Government commenced its work, that instead of 110,000 people being on the public housing waiting list, there are now 161,000 people on the list. That is the simple reality that is not mentioned in this statement. We have gone from a waiting list of slightly over 110,000 to 160,000. I say to the Senate that if the Government were honestly interested in the concerns of the homeless, we would see in this statement some analysis of the figures and some indication of the Government directing its mind at how it is going to solve the problem.

Let me turn from the general public housing list to the situation of Aboriginal Australians. In 1983 the Australian Labor Party set out in its platform that it was going to have a six-year program to house Aboriginal Australians. I suppose many Australians thought that was a good idea, as probably many of the health, education and other problems of Aboriginal people relate to the fact that so many of those people are ill-housed. But what do we actually find? We find that the Aboriginal Development Commission reports this year that the position is 6 per cent worse after 4 1/2 years of Labor government than it was when the Government set off down its track. So if we look at that particular disadvantaged section of the Australian community, we find a position of a worsening, again, of the list of those people who are seeking assistance and who are unable to get it. I think it is pathetic that the Minister has made this statement in the Senate under the guise of its being some sort of response to the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless. It is an empty shell; a sham; a hollow statement. I am amazed that Government back benchers are prepared to sit and take this total abrogation of responsibility and this failure, in the way they do, without any show of concern at all.

One looks at this statement and finds that a committee has been established and that a very well-known Australian, Bishop Hollingworth, has been involved. His work with the Brotherhood of St Laurence is well known. One involves a man such as Bishop Hollingworth because it suggests that one is genuinely interested in the concerns of the poor. Nobody in Australia would argue that Bishop Hollingworth is not concerned with the interests of the poor. However, I say that if there were any genuine interest on the part of this Government in regard to the position of the homeless in Australia the Government would make a statement that told us precisely the position of the homeless. There is no quantitative assessment of the problem in this statement. There is no attempt to assess trends with respect to the homeless, be they the young homeless or the old homeless. We get the most pathetic dressing up of apparently $1.4m worth of expenditure. That is over and above the $1 billion spent on the public housing program. I can understand why it is that on page 9 of the distributed version of the statement we find the Minister saying:
A program was developed that focused on improving our existing policies and programs and examining innovative solutions to housing problems, rather than maximum publicity.

On this occasion I wish the Government had spent a bit of the $1.4m on publicity. That publicity, provided it disclosed the truth of the position, would appal many people in Australia and would indicate the gross failures of the Government in this area.

I want to refer in this debate to the record of the Government. I have already said that there is a waiting list of more than 161,000 people for public housing. That is an increase of 50,000-plus. We have had 4 1/2 years of Labor government. I note that Senator Devereux, who is in the chamber, has complained that it took longer than he wished under the constitutional arrangements to become a Labor senator. I hope that now he is here he will take some interest in the extra 50,000 Australians on the waiting list for housing to see what can be done to help them through the policies of the Government of which he is a supporter.

We find that the number of people who are seeking housing assistance has grown under this Government. There are now 64,000 Australians waiting for home purchase assistance under State schemes-again, an increase since this Government has been in office. I have already referred to the fact that the Government cut some $468m from public housing in the Budget this year. I would say that that represents a belated concession by the Government to the failure of its other policies. I ask honourable senators to remember when the Government removed the tax concession that was available through the negative gearing of purchases of rental properties. The Opposition warned then of the contribution that would make to the housing problem in Australia. Of course, we were roundly abused and denounced by the Government, by many Ministers, including the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-by Ministers in this place as well-as being involved in the protection of some sort of illicit taxation activities. Of course, in the last few months the Government has seen the error of its ways and has reversed its decision on negative gearing. We may see some relief in the private sector which will do something to reduce the enormous increase in the public housing waiting lists that has occurred under this Government. How in the world this can be claimed to be some sort of success in the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless defies my comprehension.

We look at 1986-87 and we see a year of record high interest rates. That is one of the reasons why it was difficult for Australians to get homes. In 1986-87 we had one of the lowest number of housing starts on record with the number of starts falling 30,000 below the predicted demand. In 1987-88 housing starts are expected to fall to 42,000 houses short of that demand. We find that home owners are paying up to 17 per cent more of their incomes in mortgage repayments than they were paying a decade ago. It is not surprising that there are more people on the public housing waiting lists when such a large proportion of earned income-after tax income-is required to purchase a home. It is not surprising that more people have to line up and ask for government assistance in respect of the purchase of a home.

The real point I wish to make is that if this Government is concerned about the homeless it has to look to the fundamentals which will enable Australians to go on, in the great majority of cases, providing housing for themselves out of their own resources-leaving the Government to look after those who genuinely are unable to look after themselves. But what this Government has done is to increase vastly the pool of people who are genuinely unable to look after themselves. We are no longer talking about an unfortunate sector of society-the skid row derelicts who exist in every major city of the world, the Aboriginal fringe dwellers who exist in most of the rural areas of Australia, the people who obviously will not get respectable accommodation without the subvention of public money. The Liberal and National parties totally support the principle that we must provide housing programs for those who genuinely cannot help themselves.

The plea which I make in this debate is for the Government to stop treating this matter as one which will be solved by the application of welfare policies to an ever larger group of Australians. What is substantially required is to ensure that we again expand the pool of Australians who can look after themselves and reduce the number of those who have to call upon the state.

This Government has absolutely crucified those Australians who have to rent. We are very proud of the fact that the majority of Australians can own their own homes. More than 80 per cent of older Australians have the great benefit of owning a home and all of the studies on poverty that one can find will show that that is a very good way of insulating people from poverty in their old age. We should continue to encourage home ownership. It is a marvellous thing which has served Australia and the Australian community well. But we accept that for some people to do that is financially difficult; we accept that for some young people home ownership is obviously not necessary; we accept that there are many people who, for one reason or another, will need to rent. We have found that under this Government rent increases have raced ahead of the inflation rate and in our major population centres we have seen disastrous rent increases. In Sydney this has been 43 per cent.

Mr President, you come from Sydney and you would know the extent to which there is genuine hardship in the city of Sydney because of rent increases of that order. There have been rent increases of 23 per cent in Melbourne, a 36 per cent increase in the space of one year in my own city of Perth and 27 per cent in Brisbane.

The Government may well say, `That is why we have increased the amount of rent allowance for needy people'. But that is the whole point. This Government is producing an ever larger pool of people who are requiring assistance in a circumstance in which the Government is saying, `We have to cut back on government expenditure'. No one in this chamber could deny, with any honesty, that over the next 12 months it is quite likely that this Government will have to bear down further on government expenditure. I make that comment with no partisan intent at all. I simply say that any honourable senator who has thought about our current economic situation would agree that it is quite possible that the Government will further have to restrict government expenditure over the coming 12 months not because it wants to but because economic circumstances dictate it. We say they dictate it already; the Government is hedging but we believe that it will inevitably be drawn to that point of view. In those circumstances to suggest that the needs of the homeless in Australia will be met if we follow policies which increase the number of people requiring Government support is foolish. In a situation of declining availability of public funds to help the needy it is vitally important that the non-needy be encouraged to help themselves. It is very sad that the queues for public housing have lengthened so much under the Hawke Labor Government because that means that those genuinely needy people are less likely to receive the assistance they need.

I again refer to my earlier reference to the Aboriginal community in this country. I do so because the Special Minister of State lectured the previous Government over and over again on these issues. When she was not promising land rights legislation to take the Queensland reserves out of the hands of the Queensland Government-it was going to be the first legislative act of a Labor government-she was on about our failure to do enough for the Aboriginal people. She put out a summary of what was going to be done for the Aboriginal people as part of the talking points for Labor candidates in 1983. That summary referred to the platform of the Labor Party, which was that in six years Aboriginal people would be accommodated. They would be accommodated to a standard acceptable to them, and one devised in consultation with them. I say to the Minister that the fact that she can bring into this chamber a statement that fails to give us a single figure on the position of the homeless in this country is an absolute disgrace.

I simply wish to say that it is all very well for the Deputy Leader of the Government in this place, Senator Gareth Evans, to wax indignant about a member of the House of Representatives who, he says, is adopting tactics that he does not like. I remind the Senate of the recent rage of Senator Evans on that subject. I ask a question: When did we last hear a Labor senator express any rage about the situation of the poor in this country? When did we last hear a back bench supporter of this Government come in and express a word of serious criticism about the growth of poverty in this country, and about the appalling failure of this Government to live up to its promises? I cannot remember an occasion. If I do a Labor backbencher an injustice, I would welcome his or her involvement in this debate to remind me of the occasions when Labor members of parliament have repeated the promises that they made to the Australian people in 1983 and 1985-those promises that they would do all those things that the wicked Fraser Government did not!

I stand here as an ex-member of the wicked Fraser Government, and as one who, for a time, was responsible for welfare housing. I did not preside over the waiting lists that this Government presides over. The Minister is quite right to say that I did not spend that amount of public money. However, I also did not assist in having policies which drove people on to the public housing lists in the hordes in which they have been driven under this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want us to cut money? What is your logic?

—The logic is, Minister, that the Government is producing more and more poor people in this country, people who cannot fend for themselves. I hope that the Government will give Bishop Hollingworth the opportunity to produce a genuine assessment of the position of the homeless in this country, and to publish it without any interference from the Government. This is one of the other areas of very significant policy failure by the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I just wish that I could see some hint, on the Labor back bench, of a concern for the issues of social justice that Labor members endlessly parroted and trumpeted on about in opposition. It has been one of the greatest examples of political hypocrisy in my life time. Looking at the back benches opposite, one remembers the performance of the back bench members of the Liberal Party of Australia and National Party of Australia in government, when backbenchers were very often prepared to raise issues that were critical of the Government and difficult for the Government. I say that as a Minister who, at times, had to respond to those matters.

I believe that this statement is an example of the poverty of the Labor Party and of the loss of concern that has been so much a feature of the Hawke Government. I am pleased to have this opportunity to speak on the statement, but I am also very sorry that I have this opportunity because it represents in fact a recording of the desertion by this Government of those who most need the help of government. It is a pathetic, shabby, shoddy statement and I am sorry, on reflection, that I did not make the Minister read it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Year of Shelter for the Homeless (IYSH) has already been turned into a quarter of a million dollar publicity stunt by the Hawke Government. As the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, clearly pointed out, there has been a disastrous blowout in the number of people who are not adequately housed. Not one cent of the $1.4m allocated by the Government for the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless is being spent on providing shelter for homeless Australians. However, $226,500-I repeat that for the benefit of the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan): $226,500-is to be spent on promotion and public relations, the biggest single expenditure item in this $1.4m, which is taking almost 20 per cent of the total funding for the IYSH this year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's policy decision to refuse to direct any of these funds to `the provision of shelter for the homeless as a matter of priority' is clearly contrary to the United Nations resolution setting up the IYSH. Its grant of only $50,000 to the United Nations Commission for Human Settlement is a ludicrous response to the United Nations request to provide funding for shelter in the disadvantaged and developing countries. It is scandalous that while organisations such as the Sydney City Mission and the Matthew Talbot Hostel, which cater for the most disadvantaged of the homeless, are being so starved of funds that they cannot cope with the demand, this $1.4m of IYSH funding is being frittered away mainly on promoting the Government and providing what in many cases appears to be politically useful grants. But nothing is going to those organisations which provide shelter to the 40,000 Australians shown in a recent survey to be sleeping either out of doors or in refuges.

Instead, the Government has decided on the `primary focus' of IYSH in Australia being towards `improving the effectiveness of current housing programs and relevant aid programs'. But as these are almost entirely run by governments, State and Federal, why is there any real need for the Government to spend one-quarter of a million dollars on promotion and public relations campaigns in order to tell itself how it should fix up its own policies along with those of its four fellow Labor governments in the States? This promotional spending is really aimed at making the Government appear to be doing something positive to fix up its own inadequate or misdirected housing policies which, as Senator Chaney pointed out, have clearly failed, and which should have been under constant review as a matter of good government. Obviously, the Government has been totally incompetent in reviewing housing policies if, in fact, the situation is as Senator Chaney so outstandingly outlined it.

For many years governments of all persuasions have had policies aimed at alleviating housing related poverty, including the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, the supported accommodation assistance program, the Aboriginal Development Commission and similar arrangements. The Government's efficiency in delivering shelter for the homeless-and as Senator Chaney pointed out, under his administration in the previous Government, the number of people in this desperate plight was lower than it is now-will not be assisted one iota by a grant of $7,300 to produce a personalised account of the history of the first Fremantle housing collective, or the $3,500 used to produce a video of the 1985 National Youth Housing Conference, which just happened to take place in the Wollongong electorate of the former Minister for Housing and present Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), or the $7,000 to the Tenants Union for a national conference. Very little of the $1.4m of taxpayers' money allocated by the Government for this program will do anything positive towards the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless objective of improving the shelter of the homeless and inadequately housed by the turn of the century. But it has been a good public relations stunt by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed to hear the amount of hypocrisy flying around this chamber right now. I am sure that I shall hear a lot more in my time in this place. I have been a youth worker for 15 years. I have been working with the homeless and have seen the effect of government policies in the last 15 years. There is no party in this place, in any State or in any House, that can be proud of its record on the homeless. During the days of the Whitlam era I was chairperson of the Inner Sydney Regional Council for Social Development, a locally based, nationally integrated social planning program. Back in 1973-74 we identified the need for housing and social welfare. Those needs were identified 15 years ago. I personally have put in submission after submission to government after government about the needs of the homeless, the destitute and the unemployed. None of them has been taken up.

SPEECH.PARA: I see from the Minister's statement that the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless:
has provided a unique opportunity to re-examine housing problems and housing assistance . . .

We do not need more re-examination. We need more action. It seems that whenever funding is to be cut to the homeless, to the poor, what happens is that arrangements are re-organised. The whole thing is put together in a glossy brochure and called reform, a brand new initiative. It is a sham. The statement says:
The conditions of human settlements throughout the world are deteriorating.

Despite considerable effort by the Government and the poor themselves, the number of people living in poverty continues to grow. The statement goes on to describe the situation in the world, but it could be describing the situation in this country.

The Government talks of innovative programs to deal with housing and homelessness. I was associated with a number of attempts to introduce innovative programs to deal with homelessness and poverty. None has ever succeeded. All tried to make maximum use of the dollar and of the initiative by poor people and homeless people themselves and maximum use of community resources. In my first speech to the Senate recently I talked about young people I knew who, for one reason or another, had died. I was pretty moved then and am still moved now to think of these people. They were young people of 15 or 16 years who supposedly should have been in the prime of their lives. They were homeless, without families or support, but they are dead through drugs, suicide or whatever it may be. This issue goes across the parties and across governments. It is the responsibility of us all, of everyone in the community, to ensure that people are housed, fed and clothed. Australia's housing record is shameful. Senator Chaney was waxing indignant about this Government's record. His were crocodile tears. I worked with the homeless during the Fraser years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not the only one.
—I remind Senator Walters that the homeless and the poor were no better off during the Fraser years than they are at present under this Government.
—There were not as many.

It behoves Senator Walters, Senator Tambling and the Minister to refrain from point-scoring and from saying that one government was better than the other government, that one Prime Minister was better than another Prime Minister. I agree that in 1987 the situation for the homeless is worse than it has ever been, but I do not think it would have been any better under a coalition government than it is under this Government. It is quite likely that it would have been worse.

—I almost did, but I could not bring myself to do it. It is time that the priorities in this country were re-evaluated. —The Minister interjects to tell us of the programs introduced and continued by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on income tax rulings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
On 27 May 1987, the Senate resolved that the then Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs should consider and report on:
(a) the nature, function, ambit and adequacy of income tax rulings issued by the Commissioner of Taxation; and
(b) the process by which these rulings are formulated and disseminated.

This reference was amongst those referred to the new Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs when it was appointed as the parliamentary successor of the previous Committee on 22 September 1987.

The Committee received submissions from most of the professional organisations involved in providing taxation advice, as well as from a range of individuals and the Commonwealth Ombudsman. The Committee also received considerable assistance from the office of the Commissioner of Taxation, from whom we received two submissions. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Commissioner for his assistance. In general the submissions expressed support for the system of taxation rulings, although particular submissions took issue with particular rulings. The Committee interpreted its reference as requiring it to consider the system of taxation rulings.

The Committee noted two consistent themes in the submissions. First, whether the Commissioner's rulings should be binding, particularly, whether they should be binding upon the Commissioner. The suggestions made to the Committee included proposals to elevate Commissioner's rulings to the status of subordinate legislation, to make the rulings binding on the Commissioner only and/or to establish a system similar to that which operates pursuant to the Sales Tax Procedure Act 1934 in relation to sales tax rulings. Secondly, many submissions urged the Commissioner to consult with a greater range of individuals and organisations over the drafting of rulings.

In relation to binding rulings, the Committee has concluded that rulings should not be binding, either generally or upon the Commissioner alone. The Committee believes that the rulings cannot be made binding, on either a practical or a political level, without diluting their effectiveness and interfering with the operations of the Commissioner of Taxation. Our reasons for reaching this conclusion are set out in some detail in chapter 2 of our report. Of course, in reaching this conclusion, the Committee does not wish to be seen to be encouraging the Commissioner to disregard his rulings. The Committee endorses the Commissioner's existing practice which is to depart from his rulings only where there is good reason, such as where the tax Acts have been changed, or where the ruling was wrong.

In relation to consultation, the Committee received some evidence on the operation of the Tax Liaison Group and the consultative processes which precede the issuing of rulings. The Committee was impressed by the degree of support for the rulings system evident among the tax professionals. However, the Committee noted that many of these professional organisations urged the Commissioner to consult as widely as possible over the drafting of rulings. The Committee recognises that there are limits to the degree of consultation which is possible before the system becomes unworkable. Nonetheless, the Committee encourages the Commissioner to consult as widely as is practicable.

Some submissions argued that the Commissioner's rulings were biased against taxpayers. The Committee recognises that this allegation raises the larger question of whether the Commissioner's role is to protect the revenue on the one hand, or to assist the public on the other. If the Commissioner's role is to protect the revenue, this role will determine the decision whether to issue a ruling and the form and content of such a ruling. For example, ambiguity or uncertainty in income tax law may deter taxpayers from arranging their affairs in a particular way so as to minimise tax. The Commissioner would best protect the revenue by not issuing a ruling on the matter; second best would be to issue an unhelpful or obscure ruling. On the other hand, if the Commissioner's role is to assist the public, this would be best fulfilled by the prompt issue of clear rulings whenever requested. The two roles will not always be in conflict. In many cases, assisting the public may directly or indirectly protect the revenue.

The Committee encourages the Commissioner to maintain the long term view that in most situations the revenue is best protected by assisting the public, given that voluntary compliance is the basis on which the tax system depends to such a great extent. But the Committee has accepted that where there is a conflict between protecting the revenue and assisting the public, the needs of the revenue must take priority. The Committee does not expect the Commissioner to take a detached, academic view of the law which it is his function to administer.

Some suggestions which the Committee has picked up relate to the presentation of the rulings. The Committee agrees with the suggestion that the status of rulings should be perfectly clear to anyone reading them. The Committee has recommended that each ruling should contain an explicit warning that, firstly, the ruling does not have the force of law and, secondly, each decision made in the Australian Taxation Office will be considered upon its individual merits, as well as pursuant to any relevant ruling.

While the rulings published by the commercial publishers at least contain a reference back to Rulings No. 1, which sets out these principles, the Committee believes that rulings, as they are issued by the Australian Taxation Office, should contain an explicit caveat. The Committee also recommends that, in the interests of the users of rulings, rulings should be cross-referenced to related rulings. Similarly, the Committee recommends that the index to the rulings issued by the Commissioner should be improved, to facilitate easier access to rulings by taxation advisers and, in particular, the general public.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1987 annual report of the Australian Bicentennial Authority is by definition the last annual report that we will have from the Authority before the actual events of the Bicentenary arrive upon us with the enormous rush for which I have no doubt the majority of Australians are singularly unprepared. One particular art form tends to be the subject of very little discussion and attention. I believe it to be one of the most important art forms in Australia. I refer to the dance. Of all the cultural activities dance is perhaps the most uniting. Dance is an important part of Australia's Aboriginal culture; it is important in the cultures of all of the nations from which migrant groups have come to Australia; it is able to be understood in a way in which many other class-cultural art forms are not. For instance, very great difficulties are encountered in understanding the music of other countries, whether it happens to be Japanese, Arabic or Indian music, because of the quite different bases upon which that music is founded and the different meanings that attach to that music. Next year we will be fortunate in that one of our Bicentenary visitors will be the Twyla Tharp Dance Company, which I have had the pleasure of seeing perform in the United States of America and which in some ways is one of the leading modern dance companies in the world.
