TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Chaney, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) condemns the Government for its inadequate and inflexible response to the dramatic developments on world share markets and their consequences for the Australian economy; and
(b) calls on the Government to revise budget and labour market strategies to halt the slide in Australia's economic performance and the continuing decline in living standards.

This is a serious matter. It concerns the Government's paralysis and inactivity in the face of a dramatic international economic decline and, some commentators would say, a meltdown in the world stock exchanges. I commence by considering some of the statistical falls that have taken place over the last three weeks. From 1 October to the end of October the Australian all ordinaries index fell by 41.8 per cent. That compares with a fall of 24.5 per cent in the United States, 11.5 per cent in Japan, and 25.8 per cent in the United Kingdom. The only country that has had a comparable fall in its equivalent all ordinaries index is Hong Kong. One could rightly suspect that that is because there are quite a considerable number of Australian stocks listed on that exchange.

That being the case, it highlights the dramatic loss of investor confidence in the Australian economy and the extent to which investors are increasingly taking the view that our current economic strategy is unsustainable, that it does not reflect a responsible approach to the changes that are occurring about us and that despite all the euphoria that surrounded the supposedly balanced Budget the fundamentals have not changed-our inflation rate is significantly higher than those of our trading partners; interest rates are still two and three times higher than those of our trading partners, especially Japan; unemployment is stuck at around the 7 per cent mark; and, in many ways, we are simply going backwards. It is a matter of very considerable concern to all those who are worried about the future of the Australian economy. Indeed, the decline in our terms of trade has traditionally been one excuse proffered by the Government for explaining the sorts of problems that have beset us but, in reality, our terms of trade have been on the improve in recent months. The problem does not relate to that at all: it relates to declining productivity; declining ability to compete; wage levels that are much higher than those of our trading partners; and, in many ways, a refusal by the Government to take tight and responsible economic action.

We are often accused on this side of the chamber of economic sabotage because it is suggested that we are talking down the value of the Australian dollar. The reality is that the market will, at times, respond to statements by Ministers in relation to the value of the dollar. We saw that not so long ago with Senator Button offering some comments-perhaps unwisely from the Government's point of view-that he would like to see the dollar fall because it would assist our ability to export. There is no doubt that the comments made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) about a banana republic similarly had a fairly dramatic effect in terms of reducing the value of the Australian dollar. In recent days the Treasurer has been on the offensive in trying to quieten down the markets to restore confidence in the business community. I note in tonight's Melbourne Herald that he is in his usual modest mode in describing the Government as `experts at crisis management'. He is half right in that statement. There is a crisis, it does need to be managed, but there certainly are not the right experts in the right places. It is a belated recognition of the fact that there are some very critical problems facing the Australian economy.

The Treasurer, for clearly political reasons, is not prepared to acknowledge the need for similarly dramatic changes and is only prepared to lambaste the Opposition for what he describes as anti-gradualist policies. We make no apologies for asserting that what is desperately needed in this country are wage increases that are only a reflection of productive gains that do not simply result from--

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that include doctors?

—It includes all those who do not achieve gains in income that reflect the ability of their industry to pay and their own ability to increase the output of that industry. I would have thought that there are considerable difficulties, especially in the Public Service, in demonstrating productivity gains. Nonetheless, we are looking at a very concerted campaign to ensure that rises flow on irrespective of second tier negotiations. That is another one of those continuing tragedies that beset the Australian economy. Our productivity growth over 1986-87 was well below that of our major trading partners; indeed, it was only about one quarter of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average. It is a fundamental proposition that if we have wage increases or cost increases that exceed the rate of productivity growth and simply reflect the prevailing rate of inflation, then we will compound the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: If those increases are limited to productivity rises generally there will not be any inflation to worry about. That, of course, is one of the major reasons why Australia has an inflation rate that is out of kilter with the rest of the Western trading nations. That is a problem this Government refuses to tackle because it puts the price of industrial peace so high on the agenda that it is not prepared to take the sorts of decisions that would result in a decline in living standards, which inevitably must occur. Indeed, a decline has occurred and a further decline will ultimately continue to be forced on us if we do not get the fundamentals right.

The fall in the stock market can, I think, in some measure be attributed to the lack of responsibility on the part of the United States Government. There seems to have been almost a head in the sand approach to the twin deficits that have been allowed to operate there for very many years. I regard it as little short of tragic that the experiment that was adopted some years ago in endeavouring to reduce taxation rates was not accompanied by commensurate decreases in spending in other areas. Had that been the case, there would have been some prospect of a Budget that was not too far out of balance. But, of course, the United States has had a Budget deficit of the order of $200 billion. That, of course, has caused the American economy to be one-sided, it has caused the very significant problems in trading with Japan and West Germany and it has ultimately led those countries to lose faith in their own ability to prop up the American dollar. Indeed it has precipitated a flight of capital out of the American market, which is then washed on to the world economy. It is quite clear that the American economy has survived to this point only because it has been propped up by the intervention of those surplus trading nations in the foreign exchange markets to support the United States dollar by deliberately holding down interest rates in their own countries in order to maintain differentials in favour of the United States dollar. It is clear that their justification for doing so was that they themselves had very substantial investments in the United States which they wanted to protect. That is all very well, but ultimately the chickens come home to roost.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish the owls did.

—No doubt the Minister's friends would appreciate that, but the Americans, I think, have more problems on their minds than New Zealand. The Labor Government in control of that country seems to have grasped a lot more nettles than this Government has-with things such as a goods and services tax, corporatisation and some very significant forms of deregulation which have not flowed on to this country. That was merely an aside.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply say that the United States has in effect reaped the harvest that had been sown in the period of the last five or six years. The problem has therefore washed over, because the American economy is of such significance to Australia and, of course, to the rest of the world. Indeed, it will have a very significant impact on our own economy because global capital flows will slow. There will be less money around for foreign investment. There will be a much greater reluctance on the part of international investors to move funds around the world and we will inevitably find that our own economy will start to slow down. We will be caught in a bind, in a sense, because if we do have significant growth in our economy, if gross domestic product (GDP) increases by one percentage point-and I think the Budget prediction was that GDP would grow by some 4 per cent-it will add something like $1 billion to our import bill. That, of course, would simply compound the problem that we are faced with at present.

Having regard to the size of Australia's foreign debt, the picture is simply more gloomy as the days go by. In fact, something that caught my eye the other day in a newspaper suggested that our gross foreign debt has probably reached about $120 billion, and that changes in the exchange rate in the last week have added something like $8 billion to the total foreign debt. Every US1c fall in the value of the Australian dollar will now add about $1.5 billion to our total foreign debt. Let me remind the Senate that $1.5 billion is equal to a disastrous one month's balance of payments figure.

So it is quite clear that when we see falls of the order of 2c in a couple of days, as we have seen in the aftermath of the stock exchange collapse, what we are really talking about are very significant consequences for our balance of payments. Our current account deficit is a function of our balance of payments which feeds off the fact that we do not have exports that exceed our imports, or the revenue that we derive from exports is not in excess of the funds that we pay out for imports. That situation is simply compounded by the significant outflow on invisibles and other items that causes our current account deficit to be around the $12 billion mark. As I have indicated, every US1c fall in the exchange rates will have that sort of dramatic consequence.

So it is quite clear that we are not going to be able to see any significant decline in our gross foreign debt. The consequence of that is that investors will ultimately take the view that the serious problems are not being addressed in this country. They will not be prepared to invest here, either by direct or portfolio investment, unless there are very significant risk rewards. By that, I mean very high interest rates to cover the differential between here and overseas to guard against further devaluation effects.
I was interested to note that a recent book, Paying the Banker-Facing Australia's Foreign Debt Problem, to which a number of leading Australian economists have contributed, takes this view:
Foreign debt is climbing to the point where further overseas loans will be refused.
The critical element . . . is whether the dollar is low enough to stimulate exports and replace imports with home-grown products.
There is not much sign of that happening at present. Mr Rob Fraser, who is an economist with the Australian Mining Industry Council, said this:
One thing is certain-
in the wake of the stock exchange debacle-
the real economy will not be protected. The reason is that Australia has never been so exposed to international problems.
That exposure is there because Australia owes more than $100 billion to foreigners.
As I have pointed out, the net figure is around $80 billion but the gross figure is probably approaching $120 billion. Mr Fraser went on to say:
Moreover, the interest payments on Australia's debt are increasing at the same time as our income is falling, exactly the problem being faced by the average householder.
Every time there is a devaluation, a decrease in the value of the Australian dollar in relation to United States dollars, the cost of repayment of the capital and interest rises accordingly.

That is what is happening at the present time. If we are to become more competitive to overcome the problems that flow from Australia being prepared to pay wage rates out of line with those of our trading partners, if we are prepared to go on having productivity growth that is a quarter of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average, the only way in which we can achieve a compensation is to have a very significant cut in public sector expenditure or a very real increase in the margin of exports over imports. What Mr Fraser is saying is that the interest payments on Australia's debt are increasing at the same time as our income is falling. That is an unsustainable position. He says:
Borrowing was a legitimate means of improving exports. But it imposes a need to improve productive performance. Unfortunately, Australia has not delivered.

He is perfectly right. If we are making progress, if we are achieving significant gains on the balance of trade, if we are reducing the public sector borrowing requirement, if we are getting our fundamentals right, our dollar will increase in value and the amount that we have to repay will be less. Indeed, in all probability, the amount we will need to borrow will be less. The only justification for borrowing should be if one can be sure that there will be real growth gains and that the investment return will result from productive activity. Once we start borrowing to pay for current investment outlays, then we have a significant problem. It is rather akin to borrowing from the bank on one account to try to lower the level of an overdraft on another.

These are reasons why Senator Walsh has made no bones about the very serious difficulties that are facing Australia, and why the miraculously balanced Budget that was presented by the Treasurer only a short while ago was in fact a mirage. What Senator Walsh has said, in no uncertain terms, is that the hard ball has not been tackled, the really significant cuts in expenditure have not been made, and therefore we are going to go further down the Argentinean road.

As Senator Stone has pointed out in this chamber, on more than one occasion, probably the most significant word in that expression is `further'. In other words, Senator Walsh is acknowledging that we are already going down the Argentinean road. For those who do not appreciate the significance of that metaphor, the reality is that at the turn of the century Australia and the Argentine vied for number one position in terms of wealth. Our per capita gross national product was such that we were both commodity dependent countries with enormous potential and glowing futures. Australia has managed to dissipate its inheritance progressively over the period and we have gone from about fifth on the international table shortly after the war, to about eighteenth; so we are sliding. The Argentine has simply fallen to such an extent that it is now classically a Third World country. It has all sorts of endemic problems that beset countries that cannot handle their own economies, that find themselves the victims of periodic coups and that simply are not democracies in any shape or form.

It would be a tragedy if Senator Walsh and his colleagues, such as Senator Richardson, had in mind the view that we are going even further down the Argentinean road. That means that unless we do something about the state of the economy, unless we stop pretending that somehow all will be right, and unless we stop adopting this propaganda line that the Treasurer keeps trotting out, we will indeed be making no headway. What is needed now is a very significant U-turn rather than simply slowing down our progress along the Argentinean road.

I was interested to see an article in the Herald tonight in which the Treasurer concedes that business investment has suffered. He also concedes that there is a need for privatisation, although in his usually coy and code manner, he said that the issue of the retention of government business enterprises was long overdue, but that the critical aspect to be focused on at the present time was the current account deficit, and he did not want to be any more specific about the need for reducing public sector outlays. It is quite clear that the Treasurer again recognises the need for the total or partial divestiture of some government business enterprises, ones that do not have natural monopoly components or any national security implications. What he said even in relation to the $1 billion-worth of asset sales in the May economic statement was that it relates largely to real estate and largely to the embassy in Tokyo. He expressed a degree of confidence-and this is the justification for the gradualist approach-that because our exchange rate was moving in our favour in relation to the yen, somehow we would be able to do reasonably well out of the deal. Of course, that simply means that if the value of the Australian dollar is declining we will receive more for our asset if we have a sale in Japan. That is a fairly pathetic way of achieving solace from the state of the Australian economy. He is really rejoicing in the fact that the Australian dollar is falling and saying that because we have had to flog assets off-shore we will be able to earn at least what we anticipated we would earn in the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course he ignores the fact that our debt will be rising as the currency is going down.

—Absolutely. The sale would be a very small benefit. Of course, let us bear in mind that the Budget also relied on $1.5 billion in windfall profits from the Reserve Bank of Australia trading on overseas currencies. Therefore, we can see that the sale is a one-off situation that certainly will not be repeated next time around. Things such as capital gains sales will not be repeated in the next Budget to anything like the same extent, although I think we are talking about only $50m or so.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner rightly points out that for the sake of that one small benefit-making a virtue out of necessity-we will be paying the sort of price I have talked about; we will have had something like $8 billion added to the level of our overseas debt. It is an extraordinarily dishonest piece of propaganda for the Treasurer to be drawing comfort from the fact that we will still get back the $1 billion from the sale of assets on the one hand and yet not mention the fact that our foreign debt is exploding on the other hand. That is simply an example of the legerdemain at which the Treasurer is expert but which, one would hope, the majority of the Australian community is no longer fooled by.

Senator Walsh's comments were, of course, quite specific. He said that the new Parliament House was a scandal and that there was no need for the new Brisbane Airport. Of course, one has to assume that Senator Walsh has played a role in the decisions made in relation to these projects over the last 4 1/2 years. Of course he also gives a serve to all sorts of other areas of government expenditure. For instance, he believes that there should be an inheritance tax. We would be delighted to see the specifics of that proposal. No doubt, it will come out of the in-house wealth review undertaken in Caucus. He believes that child care should never have been enticed from the private sector and that there is a strong argument for tertiary fees. That is all good stuff. We would like to think that Senator Walsh had some clout in the scheme of things. At least he has the intellectual rigor to acknowledge the severity of the problem, but he does not seem to have the intestinal fortitude to deliver the goods.

He does have a hit list of 13 major spending programs that would have to be cut to limit the future growth in the Commonwealth Budget. Maybe they were just words. Maybe they were just meant to take the shine off the Budget. Maybe they were meant to bring the Treasurer down a peg. Certainly, they had the effect of earning him a rebuke from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). If those words are to be taken at face value-if we give the man some spiritual credit for meaning what he said-they are an indication that he acknowledges that dramatic steps need to be taken, that the gradualist approach is wrong and that the Treasurer simply is attempting to fool the people. I will not use that hackneyed, Titanic comparison, but I would have thought that it was very similar in terms of non-response to a critical situation.

Of course Senator Walsh's comments were not simply his own. They were based on a report of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) which earlier in the year made the situation very clear. No doubt the IMF had been in consultation with the Australian Government, the Treasurer and Treasury officials. It expressed the view in a report earlier this year that although some Government policy initiatives had been taken there was a need for significantly more progress in reducing public sector debt and a need for cuts in socially and politically difficult spending programs. It is clear that Senator Walsh was building on those remarks. In fact, in a throwaway line he suggested at one stage that the IMF might be forced to intervene to solve the foreign debt problems in the event of another terms of trade collapse. That is about the only problem that has not beset the economy in recent times.

Our terms of trade have not continued to decline but everything else has gone awry. Yet we have had virtually no response apart from this synthetic, cosmetic public relations exercise that the Treasurer is currently embarking on. It is clear that Senator Walsh is a voice in the wilderness because he is at least interested in tackling the fundamentals whereas the Treasurer, for his own agenda purposes, wants to present an impression of calm and is not prepared to face up to these very real difficulties.

It is absolute nonsense to say in the wake of the collapse of the stock market in Australia-it has probably happened to a greater extent in the Australian stock exchange than in any other stock exchange in the world-that we can simply sit back and pretend that it is a problem from which the economy is insulated. It is not. The Government has a very real capacity to respond. It has an obligation in terms of consumer confidence and in terms of business investment but it has done virtually nothing.

It is very significant that today yet another pin was pulled out from the Government's platform by a report from the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). It demolished yet another claim to economic respectability on the part of the Government. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has been the principal architect of a whole range of assistance packages-the motor vehicle industry plan, the heavy engineering plan, the steel plan and the textiles, clothing and footwear plan-and they have been lauded as very sensible and, presumably, gradualist responses. The IAC has exposed the inadequacy of that attitude and it is really saying that it is no more than the old protectionist trade barriers in disguise. It is another form of hooking industry on to the lifeline of government and of becoming dependent upon government assistance, what is now known as positive assistance. This is a euphemism for government handouts.

The IAC has pulled no punches. It is very interesting that these days the Australian Financial Review is very much a political journal. The stories on page one, in the course of describing the strident comments of the IAC, take time out to give us the political response from the higher echelons of government. It states:

It is understood that the purist tone of the report has antagonised not only the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce but also the IAC's new found supporter and protector, the Federal Treasurer.

All honourable senators will be aware that there was a very real empire tussle between those two Ministers following the Government's return to office. The Treasurer won out; the responsibility of the IAC was transferred from the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce to Treasury, and this is its first effort.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to express my opposition to the sentiments of this motion and the direction which it takes. It is interesting to have a close analysis of the motion before the Senate, which was moved by Senator Chaney, and to look at its contradictions. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Government for its inadequate and inflexible response to the dramatic developments on world share markets . . .

We are then asked to call on the Government to revise its Budget and labour market strategies to halt the slide in Australia's economic performance. In essence, what we have been asked to do is to look at the share crisis and, in the words of one of my colleagues, to subsidise the gambling losses of the bosses by making the workers and the Australian population pay.

Senator Messner, in his normal shell of ignorance, is shaking his head but he should read the motion before us. If he does he will see that that is basically the underlying philosophy. The Government is attacked for being inflexible in its approach to the share crisis. I ask the Senate to recollect the days of Fraser, Lynch, Howard and Stone when the Australian economy was in difficulties. Their response was very much the one that has been proposed today. We remember that the great wages freeze touted before an election was the answer to Australia's problems. All that did was induce greater and greater recessionary trends. What we are offered today in this motion is very much the old trick from failed magicians.

It is also interesting to discuss this motion on a day when we have spent the best part of 1 1/2 to 2 hours discussing Australia's response to homelessness. Opposition speaker after Opposition speaker has been grandstanding about the Government's neglect of that area. What this sort of motion would embody as a macroeconomic response to Australia's problems is a cutback in budgetary and labour market resources. What is implied in it is a direct cutback in resources in areas such as those that we discussed this afternoon. The Opposition is trying to have it both ways. It wants, on the one hand, to show care for the homeless by advocating greater Government initiatives and responses while, on the other hand, it is saying half an hour later that we should cut back even further.

Senator Alston made a couple of points to which I wish to respond. He talked about the Government's Budget and what he sees as hollow figures within it. However, I ask Senator Alston and other members of the Opposition to compare the honesty in this Government's Budget and its final outcome with the sorts of responses that we had under Howard, Stone and Fraser for eight years. Their greatest trick was to defer expenditure, especially before an election. They would bodgie up the figures by ensuring that payments were made outside the relevant budgetary period and to ensure that their budgetary deficit looked good in the eyes of the Australian people. Let us also ask the Senate to remember that the day after they lost government in March 1983, the then Secretary to the Treasury, now the Leader of the National Party of Australia in this chamber, and his advisers, came to the Government and said, in essence, `We are stuck with a $9.6 billion deficit. It is up to you to fix it up'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! That is simply false.

—Let us look at the contributions from the Opposition. The failed personality of Tasmanian talkback radio interjects, as he always does. The new Senator Vigor wants to make his contribution. What we have had this afternoon from Senator Alston is a continuation of carping criticism. He must have a real problem at the moment-a real conflict of interest. On the one hand, he and his colleagues have probably got heaps invested on the share market and they would love to ensure that the market does not slide any further. Senator Messner may not have, because he is not economically astute enough to get into these things like some of his colleagues--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. It is highly disorderly to impute any sort of motive to a member of the Opposition when he has been speaking to a matter, particularly one of such significance. I ask for that imputation against Senator Alston to be withdrawn.

—I withdraw that imputation; I do not know why, but in deference to the point of order and without wanting to debate it. The point is that, on the one hand, Opposition senators would love to criticise the Government for not responding, and in doing so, raise the heat of the crisis. On the other hand, they must be losing heaps of money on the share market.

SPEECH.PARA: What this Government has been about, over our 4 1/2 years in office, has been very much a flexible, responsive, economic approach, and that should be remembered by the Opposition and the Australian people. We also recognise that we do not live alone in this world. When we listen to a 20- or 30-minute speech from the Opposition about our economic problems and the share crisis without one reference to the fact that Wall Street has collapsed, as have the Tokyo and London markets, or one reference to international trends, we have to ask ourselves who the inflexible ideologues in this place are. In essence, the basic problem that has struck Australia over the last couple of years, particularly with the share crisis, is the international one. The big economies of the world have failed in their responsibilities. That is the basic point that people should recognise.

Take the United States of America, crippled under a failed, senile leadership, not only politically but also economically. It has failed to respond to its Budget deficit time and time again, despite the calls of economists in the States and of thinkers throughout the world. It is saddled with a President in his dying stages of office who, if he were to fulfil his responsibilities to the Western world, to Western economics and to the capitalist system that he so proudly stands for, would have no other option but to resign today and let someone else with complete competence take over. That would be the greatest psychological boost to world economies that could be made by any one person at the moment. But I suppose that he would have enough trouble trying to sign his name on the resignation paper.

For some time now all economists have been saying that the two major industrial economies, Japan and West Germany, have responsibilities to expand their own markets. All that they have been prepared to do is exploit the United States of America as an easy market. We are suffering now from the market having come down at the end of a number of years of grinding collapse. The markets have said `enough is enough' and that they will take the decision-making out of the hands of politicians. Essentially, that is what is happening world-wide.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why have Australia's markets gone down further than those of Japan and America?

—Senator Messner makes some point about deficits. Let us look at Australia's response in terms of deficits. In the last 12 months-between August 1986 and September 1987-Australia actually cut its budgetary deficit outlays by $7 billion. In equivalent terms, were the United States to take the same sort of action, it would cut its Budget deficit by $175 billion. It has not moved marginally towards fulfilling its responsibilities to the Western world.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has been asked to revise Budget and labour market strategies. Let us have a look at this Government's labour market strategy-the pivotal part of the motion before the Senate. It is significant to note that growth in labour costs under the Hawke Labor Government has moderated substantially-and continues to moderate. Recent earnings data continue to demonstrate the significant restraint exercised by Australian wage and salary earners. Senator Messner might smirk, but the reality is that average earnings rose by 6.3 per cent a year in the June quarter of 1987 and by 6.6 per cent in the 1986-87 financial year. This compares with an average rate of 11.9 per cent under the Fraser-Howard-Stone troika. Wages growth has been well and truly below prices growth in recent years. That should also be acknowledged. When we are called upon to look at labour market strategies and to defer and freeze wage increases and so on, we should point out that the Australian worker has well and truly made his or her sacrifice. As a result of the restraints shown by the Australian worker over the last few years, the index of real unit labour costs has fallen by 8.7 per cent since 1982-83. The Opposition really cannot argue about that. If it were to be consistent and honest, it would not include this reference to labour market strategy in a shonky motion before the Senate.

The other factor relating to growth in labour costs is on-costs-not the direct labour costs, but the on-costs. They also have been reduced quite substantially and are far lower than they were under previous conservative governments. But what we are being asked to do now is what I said earlier. Workers are being asked to subsidise the bosses' gambling profits. The Opposition has to acknowledge that this share crisis has come at a time when world economies are growing faster than had been anticipated six to nine months ago. The crash also came after the bull phase in the share markets had been going on for five solid years. The correction had to come some time; it has come now. The reality is that we had inflated share prices for so long that the good economic managers on the other side of the chamber knew that the correction had to occur and privately they will say so. That correction has taken place. But as a government our response was not to say `Well, that is it-we will wipe our hands clean of it'. The Government has responded and continues to take a flexible responsive attitude to the problem.

We recognise that we cannot escape from being affected by the recent turbulence. We recognise that we need to have in place an effective economic strategy for the long haul-not for today and not for tomorrow. We also feel that it is important to recognise that if we were to panic now, if we were to respond to the plaintive and frenetic pleas of the Opposition, all that would do is to destabilise the market and the economy even more. Good economic managers do not jerk around in the dark. We are continuing our effective long term policy, monitoring developments and responding in a planned way-something the Opposition or its financial spokesmen do not know about.

The Government's first response was to recognise the need to provide for the heightened demand for liquidity in the financial system-something we rarely hear about from Opposition members. The Reserve Bank made clear its recognition of the need for adequate liquidity in the short term and responded accordingly. Our second response was not to freeze the wage rises due to the work force under the first tier arrangements agreed to between government and labour organisations. It would have been short-sighted in the extreme to withdraw our earlier commitment and to support this increase. One can imagine the sort of economic turmoil and destabilisation, a return to the Fraser days of industrial conflict, if one were to load that into the current system as it now runs and see what the computers on Wall Street would do. We have in place, and will continue to have in place, an effective and flexible means of wage restraint and wage negotiation that has been basic to this Government's economic management goals and has served the Australian economy well. Thirdly, we responded to those who have called for an immediate mini-Budget-demands that were made well and truly before any rational or worthwhile assessment can be made of the impact of what has occurred over the past couple of weeks. As I said earlier, a haphazard instantaneous response would only have increased instability, and the Opposition should be aware of that.

Let me respond to Senator Alston who mentioned the report of the Industries Assistance Commission. This Government does not shy away from the fact that basic to our economic future is the living standards of the work force. We do not shy away from the fact that we have commitments in certain industries, or that we need to plan our economy and industries within it for restructuring. The ultimate goal of the Australian Government is to ensure that we can tap into international markets so that our domestic markets and industries can be competitive. We have a commitment to structural adjustment and to government assistance. That also is one of the basic planks of economic management.

I reject the Opposition's motion on two grounds. It is inconsistent, tired, old, ideological rhetoric which the conservative parties always come up with in this place. Secondly, it is forged out of unreality. It is a frenetic response and would have no other effect than to destabilise the market at a time when it needs stability and it is also based on inconsistencies. What we have seen in the Senate this afternoon in this debate, and the earlier debate on the Government's response to homelessness, is total hypocrisy. On the one hand, Opposition senators say that more expenditure is needed to combat homelessness; on the other hand they suggest in the motion greater cutbacks in the Budget. The greatest responsibility which the Opposition has in this place is to the Australian people-and that is to come up with clear, consistent, rational and coherent policies. This afternoon has shown the Opposition's bankruptcy in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus's contribution to this debate underlines one of the enormous dilemmas facing this Labor Government. Even when it moves in the direction of having policies that might almost be appropriate it is hag-ridden by its left wing. Its capacity, its scope for movement, flexibility and appropriate economic policies is severely limited. In the present situation it is inhibited by the fact that the bulk of the Labor Party has not and generally will not agree to the sorts of economic policies which are clearly required and which the Department of the Treasury is advising the Treasurer (Mr Keating) should be pursued. One imagines from the way the Treasurer speaks, rather than acts, to groups and to people overseas that he recognises and accepts them as the right course of action.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bolkus's peroration about tired, ideological rhetoric applies so appropriately to the incredible nonsense he came out with. He said that we need stability above all else-forget reality. Reality has nothing to do with what Senator Bolkus said about the economy. His socialist objective is an imposed stability, even though stability may be totally inappropriate when there is a need for massive flexibility. Talking about rhetoric, honourable senators heard his claim that the present situation, as we describe it, would involve a subsidising of the bosses' gambling losses by the workers. Have honourable senators ever heard such pathetic, tired rhetoric at a time when there is a need for positive action to correct a situation which is clearly not being adequately met by the Budget brought down in September?

The final point that should be made about Senator Bolkus's pathetic contribution to this serious matter is his claim that the Government's `successes' in various areas showed that we were doing much better than we have done in the past. The only measure of success is that which relates to the activities of our trading partners. It is no good saying that we are getting inflation down compared with what it was last year-it was ludicrously high under this Government-unless we get it down to a level which compares favourably with the levels of our trading competitors. The fact is that we are not doing so.

Under this Government, our costs relative to those of our major trading partners and to those of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development nations have been appalling. Our inflation rate compared with those of our major trading partners is the worst in post-war history under this Government. It is absolute nonsense to talk about how inflation is not as bad in absolute terms as it was last year or the year before. The reality is that the only measure we can afford to regard seriously is the measure of how we compare. In a comparison of Australia with the rest of the world the situation is disastrous. That is why we are now so vulnerable to the economic changes and to the threats that face us. That is why I support with great vigour Senator Chaney's motion:
That the Senate-
(a) condemns the Government for its inadequate and inflexible response to the dramatic developments on world share markets and their consequences for the Australian economy; and
(b) calls on the Government to revise budget and labour market strategies to halt the slide in Australia's economic performance and the continuing decline in living standards.

In doing so, I remind the Senate of the thrust of the reply of the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, to the Budget Speech. He quite correctly observed that the Budget did nothing to recognise the vulnerability of the Australian economy to changing international conditions. He said:
The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has brought down a Budget which seeks to paint a coat of veneer over a brittle and fragile economy.
My fear . . . and the fear of the Opposition, is that Labor's fifth Budget will not, as time passes, match the extravagant praise heaped upon it in recent days.
On behalf of the Opposition, I simply say: Let the buyer beware.

Of course, that line of argument has been overwhelmingly endorsed by subsequent events. The fact is that we do have a brittle economy and, because of major changes in the world economic situation, the risk taking nature of that Budget has now been exposed. As a result, it is now clear that our ability to deal with the Australian economy and Australian living standards and our chances of trading ourselves out of our disastrous balance of trade problems and our overwhelming international debt have been massively diminished by the inappropriate nature of that Budget.

Let us just see exactly what the problem from overseas is. I will quote from Salomon Brothers Inc., a major American company of brokers and advisers which in fact advises the present Australian Government. The Treasurer has often been happy to quote Salomon Brothers when it suited him. I will quote from the comments by Henry Kaufman which were put out by Salomon Brothers on 23 October to outline that this stock market crash is not simply something that affects the rich or the punters on the stock market. It was pointed out that not only will it affect the world economies but also it will have an enormous impact on the Australian economy as a supplier to and trader with the United States and those other major economies, such as Japan, which deal so significantly with the United States. To pretend that this is something that does not affect Australia-as the Treasurer tried to do for the first week or so of the stock market crash-is absolutely absurd. We also heard the sort of politics of envy from Senator Bolkus, who talked about avoiding any measures that would simply offset the gambling losses of the rich. This is not only to avoid the reality of what is happening; it is deliberately to seek to hide it from the Australian people for some sort of nonsensical political purpose. I will now read from Salomon Brothers market comments, in which it is said:

The collapse in stock prices has altered the immediate prospects for world economic growth, inflation and interest rates. It is premature to quantify these effects, although the direction is clear: Growth will be weaker, inflation will be lower, and interest rates will decline further-

that is around the rest of the world, I stress, not necessarily in Australia. Some of these elements will take place in Australia. Growth will certainly be weaker in Australia. Inflation may be lower, but I doubt it in view of the fall of the Australian dollar which will, of course, push up the price of imports and, as a result, increase the level of inflation. Interest rates will decline further worldwide, but probably not in Australia as interest rates may have to be pushed up to defend the Australian dollar. In any event, I continue with what Salomons had to say:

Real growth in the United States will likely slow in the fourth quarter of this year . . . Moreover, economic activity may well contract in the first quarter of next year. United States economic weakness will also trim growth among our major trading partners.
As far as Australia is concerned, America is a major trading partner. Salomons continues:

By itself, the contraction of wealth would dampen United States consumer and business spending. More important, the extremely uncertain economic and financial environment resulting from the plunge and unprecedented volatility in most financial markets may well result in a retrenchment in spending for big-ticket consumable durables, new houses and new investment projects. Growth in United States corporate profits, in turn, will be pared substantially.
These sharply diminished demands will trim imports-
I interpolate, including imports from Australia-
and narrow the US trade deficit. The drop in imports will reduce growth prospects overseas . . .

Salomons is clearly saying there that Australia's growth prospects will be diminished, that there will be a drop in imports, which will reduce growth prospects overseas. Certainly that is a matter of significance, not simply because of our exports directly to the United States but because of the enormous impact this will have on the Japanese economy on which such a large volume of Australia's exports depends. Salomons continues by saying that growth prospects will be reduced overseas `notably in Japan and debtor nations, but also for our major trading partners'. Salomons goes on to say:
Over the near term, US inflation will stabilize at the recent 3 1/2 per cent-4 per cent annual rate and we do not expect significant upward pressure on prices.

In other words, in the United States there will be no upward pressure on prices and a stabilising of inflation. But, of course, here, because of our devaluation, we are going to see an inevitable increase in inflationary pressures.

The Government is saying that there is no need to do anything at all because everything is right-the economic policy settings are right; there is no need to worry and no need to fuss. This attitude reminds me of the 1984-85 financial year when the Government kept saying that everything was wonderful and the Opposition was described as disgraceful, just as it has been described in the last few days, for suggesting that the Government was wrong. In those days, anyone who suggested that perhaps the Australian economy was not in the very best of hands, to adopt a line from one Li'l Abner, was subjected to personal abuse from the Treasurer. The country was certainly not in the very best of hands then.

It was only a little while later, having denied that there was any risk or any threat, that we then saw the Treasurer admitting that Australia ran the risk of becoming a banana republic. He did this, having denied that there was any such risk and having abused those, particularly members of the Opposition, who had been warning of the consequences of inappropriate, ridiculous policies. The sort of arrogance that Mr Keating displayed at that time, which was shown to be so wrong, is being repeated now. That arrogance might be all very well for political purposes. Mr Keating might get nice headlines and he might get noted by the media. The reality is that that arrogance is now a threat to Australia's economic future. That arrogance prevents him from conceding that maybe the Opposition is right, maybe the Opposition is correct, bearing in mind what organisations such as the Salomon Brothers say is going to happen. That arrogance, for some extraordinary reason, drives him to the view that he should not consider change, that he should not recognise the real threats that are developing. As I said, that arrogance is a real threat. It is the personality of the Treasurer that now probably poses the biggest single threat to Australia's economic future. The Treasurer refuses to recognise the threats posed by this massive change in the economic outlook that has developed since the world stock market crash.

One of the interesting things that have happened in the last couple of weeks has been the 10 per cent devaluation of the Australian dollar. The extraordinary thing is that this Government has a vested interest in that devaluation, simply because of the curious impact of the value, for stock valuation purposes, of foreign currency held by the Reserve Bank of Australia as our foreign reserves. Every time the Australian dollar is devalued the relative value, in Australian dollar terms, of the Reserve Bank's holdings of Deutsche marks, United States dollars, pounds sterling, the yen and so on, increases-not in real terms, but in terms of its relationship with the Australian dollar. So when the Reserve Bank last week came in strongly, massively buying Australian dollars, it was in fact taking a paper profit, and that paper profit is going towards balancing this Government's Budget.

This Government, as I said, has a clear vested interest in this kind of devaluation, in order to resolve its budgetary problems, particularly as there are going to be some real difficulties in meeting other Budget revenue targets and, as I pointed out yesterday in the debate on the income tax Bills, particularly in view of the ludicrously large estimate given by the Government in the Budget Papers of the increase in provisional tax collections next year. It has said there will be an 11 per cent rise, which of course is self-evidently nonsensical after the stock market fall.

There are clearly serious problems ahead of us. For example, there is the prospect of a further bad balance of payments figure on the current account in a couple of weeks time. I would not be surprised if it got up as high as $1.5 billion, which of course will indicate a far higher outcome for the full financial year than the estimate of $11.5 billion which is contained in the Budget Papers. The situation has been highlighted and dramatised by the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard. He asked a question of Mr Keating yesterday, in the House of Representatives, which I believe encapsulated the sorts of problems that our economy faces. Mr Howard asked the Treasurer whether he was aware of an article in the Wall Street Journal which said that `a weaker Australian dollar will lead to a tightening of monetary policy and a lifting of interest rates'. He asked whether the Treasurer was aware of the fact that:

. . . the Australian stock market has fallen by 44 per cent since late September-considerably more than major overseas markets? Is it true that the Australian dollar has fallen by 10 per cent against the world's major currencies since its post-Budget peak on 22 September? Is it a fact that Australia's inflation rate runs at more than double the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average? Is it a fact that Australia's gross foreign debt is now 42 per cent of gross domestic product, compared with 21 per cent in June 1983?
This Government has certainly made a mess of that. He went on:
Is it a fact that our current account deficit is the second largest in the Western world? . . .
Is it a fact that the Government has supported an across the board wage increase at a time when nominal wage increases run far ahead of those of our major trading partners?
He ended up by asking:

Is it not time for the Treasurer to stop lecturing the rest of the world and to come clean with the Australian people as to why Australia is performing so badly and, most importantly, what he intends to do about it?

That is the crux. What does the Treasurer intend to do about the fact that so many of the bases on which this Budget was founded, the shifting sands of assumptions, have now been so clearly revealed to have no chance whatsoever of being sustained, and therefore the Budget outcomes will not be reached, and of course, the Australian economy will suffer severely from the continued incompetence of this Government. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) relating to his recent overseas visit.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
On 9-26 October, I visited the United States, Canada, Ireland, Switzerland and Yugoslavia. In making this report to Parliament on my visits, I will focus most closely on four themes.

First, a central element of my activities abroad was the continued advocacy, in a number of important forums, of the cause which stands as essential to Australia's long-term prosperity: trade liberalisation.

Second, at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) in Vancouver, I pursued a number of issues of importance to Australia including, most particularly, the situation in Fiji and southern Africa.
Third, my visits to Ireland and Yugoslavia allowed me to cement even more firmly the close and productive ties of kinship that link Australia and those countries.
Finally, I engaged in constructive talks with the United States Secretary of State George Shultz relating to Australia's vital alliance with the United States.
TRADE LIBERALISATION

There should be no dispute with the statement that the interests of both Australia and the world would be best served by the freeing up of the international trading system. Yet the political will needed internationally to translate that logically unassailable truth into effective reform of the trading system, and to defy the rising tide of protectionism, still needs bolstering-and, of most immediate impact for Australia, there needs to be the political will to phase down and ultimately eliminate the high and growing levels of agricultural subsidies.

Accordingly, I took every opportunity during my trip to argue the merits of trade liberalisation, to marshal support for that goal, to demonstrate Australia's active commitment to it, and to help show the way forward towards it.
In particular, I addressed the issue of trade liberalisation in public speeches in San Diego and Geneva, and at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.
It was also an important element of my bilateral discussions, to which I will return later.
San Diego

The chief purpose of my visit to San Diego was to deliver a speech to the Australian-American Chamber of Commerce on bilateral and multilateral trading issues, and their impact on the close relationship between Australia and the United States.

San Diego was an especially appropriate venue for my address, for two reasons. First, because San Diego is on the Pacific Rim, it is part of the fastest growing and most dynamic region in the world. The fortunes of the countries of the Pacific Rim, including Australia and the United States, will depend crucially upon the success of the new round of multilateral trade negotiations and upon the ability of the major economies to remedy their structural imbalances through the right macroeconomic and industry restructuring policies.

Second, San Diego is the home base of the United States Pacific Surface Fleet and the site of significant defence-related manufacturing. Australia is the second largest cash purchaser of American defence equipment-a fact which contributes significantly to the favourable United States balance in trade with us.

The theme of my San Diego speech was that world economic tensions, reflected in massive external imbalances, could only be resolved satisfactorily if the major economies implemented appropriate domestic policies coupled with open trading policies. I noted that there is some evidence that domestic policies and the external imbalances had begun to adjust appropriately in certain countries but that much more needed to be done. Subsequent events in the financial markets have dramatically underscored the latter point.

I noted with particular concern, however, that in some quarters in America, protectionist pressures had been intensifying. Australia has a first class alliance with the United States, which we value, and we are a nation of significant strategic value to the United States. Our alliance is firm and secure, yet Australians may be the victims of the mounting protectionist pressure within the United States Congress. We are also concerned at the possibility that the United States may seek to resolve its trade imbalance with Japan at Australia's expense through non-commercial deals.
In short, I told my American audience that Australians would not tolerate being regarded by the United States as first-class allies but second-class friends.

I noted that the Administration had shown great determination in resisting those pressures to date and called upon it to maintain that resistance in protecting Australia's legitimate trading interests and with it, the strength of the Australian-American relationship.
Vancouver CHOGM

The Commonwealth, as an association of nations ranging in size and wealth from the populous and the economically powerful to the debt-prone and the minuscule, speaks with a unique and powerful voice on world economic issues.

It was my honour to lead the CHOGM discussion on the world economy. After outlining major developments on the world economic scene since the Nassau meeting of CHOGM I identified the main challenges for the future. In examining global economic prospects I repeated my message of San Diego that the enhancement of world growth depended upon the commitment of governments to steady rectification of fundamental domestic and external imbalances, coupled with an open trading system.

Owing to their size and influence the major economies had a special obligation to rectify their structural imbalances and I called on the Commonwealth to use all its influence to encourage those major countries to accelerate the processes of adjustment and to maximise low-inflation world growth.

In turning to the particulars of international trading problems I acknowledged one important step forward that had been taken since Nassau-the launching of the Uruguay round of multilateral trade negotiations. Nevertheless protectionist pressures are still grave, especially because of the trans-Atlantic agricultural subsidies war and the increasing strength of calls for bilateral solutions to trade deficits.

I suggested the Commonwealth could make a valuable contribution by supporting the momentum for trade reform. Consequently, I supported Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's idea of a Declaration on World Trade by Commonwealth Heads of Government.

I proposed that the Heads of Government declare that we remain gravely concerned by and firmly opposed to protectionist measures; that we stand for trade liberalisation; that we support a strong, credible and working GATT; and that we agree on the crucial need for reform of all distorting and indefensible agricultural policies. Such a declaration was drafted and was adopted by the Commonwealth leaders.

The following is a copy of the Vancouver Declaration on World Trade. It is entirely consistent with the thrust of the Government's policies on international trade and will serve as a useful reference point to reinforce the pressure we will be seeking to maintain on this vital issue.
THE VANCOUVER DECLARATION ON WORLD TRADE

The Commonwealth leaders representing a wide range of both developed and developing countries note with grave concern rising global protectionist pressures. Continuing implementation of protectionist measures would be counter-productive, would increase the risk of further exchange rate instability and would exacerbate the problems of development and indebtedness. Trade restrictions affect particularly the exports and growth prospects of developing countries and their ability to service debt all of which in turn impact adversely on the economies of the industrial countries.

We welcome the progress of negotiations in the Uruguay Round covering a range of important subjects. We will work for a balanced outcome to develop a more open, viable and durable multilateral trading system to promote growth and development. We recognise the growing importance and the asymmetrical position of developing countries in the trading system. This underlines the need to give special consideration to their interests within the agreed framework of the Uruguay Round. It is essential that the Punta del Este commitments on ``standstill'' and ``rollback'' be fully respected and implemented.

We agree on the crucial need for reform of all trade distorting agricultural policies, both domestic and international. We urge early action on agriculture in the Uruguay Round so as to reduce the uncertainty, imbalances and instability in world markets. This will benefit both developed and developing countries.

A strong, credible working GATT is essential to the well-being of all trading countries and is the best bulwark against mounting protectionist pressures. The function of the GATT should be improved through enhancing its role in maintaining an open multilateral system and its capacity in the area of dispute settlement. We hope that the negotiations will make sufficient progress on agriculture and other key subjects to enable a mid-term ministerial review of the Uruguay Round as allowed for in the Punta del Este Declaration.

We welcome the assistance which the Commonwealth Secretariat is providing to member governments in the trade field, including the re-establishment of a Trade Adviser's Office in Geneva and increased levels of technical support, and we request the Secretary-General to continue to give priority to work in this field. In addition, the larger States of the Commonwealth undertake to assist developing countries, including smaller States, through regular consultations and trade policy training programmes.
