15 October 1987
Geneva
My visit to Geneva was primarily for the purpose of addressing representatives of the Contracting Parties to the GATT. That address allowed me to do two important things.

First, I announced that Australia was prepared to negotiate a broad package of measures to reduce overall levels of effective assistance to Australian industry-including tariffs-as part of a broad-based multilateral approach. I said that in this context Australia was prepared to eliminate, over an appropriate implementation phase, all quantitative import measures designed to protect domestic industry. This means we would phase out all our quantitative restrictions, including tariff quotas, licensing and embargoes.

I stressed that we would be looking to our trading partners to reciprocate this offer by making similar reductions in their effective rates of industry assistance-not only tariffs but the range of non-tariff measures and subsidies.

Second, I had the honour on behalf of the Cairns Group of Fair Trading Nations to present the Group's proposals for agricultural trade reform. Honourable Members will recall that the Cairns Group was established following a meeting, held in Cairns in August 1986 under the chairmanship of the then Trade Minister John Dawkins, of representatives of 14 fair-trading nations. Cairns Group members were frustrated by the slow process towards freer trade being made by the major economies-in particular the US, the European Community and Japan. Since that meeting the Cairns Group has established its credentials as the vital third force in agricultural trade negotiations.

The Cairns Group's proposal which I launched contains three elements: a long-term objective of the elimination of subsidies and market barriers, within ten years at most; a framework for the rules and parameters necessary during the phase down period and a set of priorities for change; and immediate relief from the worst subsidies and market distortions, in recognition of the crisis facing world agricultural trade.

Unlike the proposals of the United States and the EC, the Cairns Group proposal focuses in detail on the reform period and the mechanisms required to achieve a free and open agricultural trading system. It gives priority to phasing out those measures that most disrupt trade and provides for the greatest distorters to make the greatest contribution to reform.

In my address I also noted the importance Australia attaches to developing rules and procedures to encourage freer trade in services. That is an area long neglected by GATT which needs to be addressed in the Uruguay round.
My address was the first in the GATT's 40-year history made by a Head of Government, and I trust it will have augmented the prestige and influence of that organisation.
I believe the speech was well received and gave Australia, and the Cairns Group, new prominence in GATT at a crucial stage of the negotiations about the future of world trade.
COMMONWEALTH HEADS OF GOVERNMENT MEETING

The Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Vancouver, 13-17 October addressed a very wide range of issues and also provided a valuable opportunity for bilateral discussions with many of the other 44 countries represented.
In describing the outcome I shall not attempt to be comprehensive; I draw the attention of honourable members to the Communique of the meeting.

CHOGM provided the first opportunity for the Commonwealth to consider the tragic events which have taken place in Fiji this year. It permitted those countries which, like Australia, are members of the South Pacific Forum, to carry forward the consultations held in Apia in May.

Our discussions were frank and intensive. Without in any way detracting from the admirable commitment and steadfastness of the Governor-General through the crisis, it was clear by the time CHOGM convened that Ratu Sir Penaia Ganilau no longer exercised authority in any other than a purely formal sense.
Therefore, we recognised the need to address the situation in Fiji as it was, rather than on the basis of wishful thinking or a fiction about who exercised real authority in that troubled country.

This was clear to me from the outset of the gathering in Vancouver and was accepted by virtually everyone to whom I spoke. Some who were either unable, or refused, to grasp this fact, and in consequence made a number of quite silly observations at the time, were quickly exposed in the light of immediate developments.

On 14 October Heads of Government were informed that the Governor-General of Fiji had advised The Queen that his endeavours to provide constitutional government had proved in vain. He had requested The Queen to relieve him of his appointment with immediate effect. We were informed, as background for our discussion, that a Republic was now to be regarded as in being in Fiji and that The Queen had ceased to be Head of State in Fiji.

Importantly, Her Majesty expressed the hope that Heads of Government would have uppermost in their minds the question of how best the interests of all the people of Fiji, of whatever race, could be safeguarded under a Republican form of government. The discussions at CHOGM proceeded on that footing.
Notwithstanding differences of nuance in particular national positions, a common view was evident at Vancouver on a number of key propositions.

All those present at CHOGM considered the principal challenge in the period immediately ahead to be the need to achieve a new political structure in Fiji which was satisfactory in terms of the legitimate aspirations and rights of all the people of Fiji.
A fundamental point of agreement was that the problems confronting Fiji were ultimately for the people of Fiji themselves to resolve.

Above all I consider there was agreement on the key objective which now needed to guide our thinking: encouraging those in authority in Fiji to adopt policies of moderation and to chart a course offering the hope of a republic decent and democratic in character rather than oppressive and authoritarian.

Accordingly, there was a willingness in Vancouver for the Commonwealth to offer to help Fiji during the critical formative period in which a new political structure will be fashioned. Heads of Government attached importance to foundations being laid which were consistent with the Commonwealth principles which I have described.
It was clear furthermore that the character of the future government in Fiji will influence views taken by Commonwealth countries on the question of Fiji's readmission to the association.
This then was the thinking which informed the statement made by CHOGM on Fiji and which I quote:

``Commonwealth leaders acknowledged that on the basis of established Commonwealth conventions Fiji's membership of the Commonwealth lapsed with the emergence of the Republic on 15 October. They viewed with sadness the developments in Fiji and hoped for a resolution of the problem by the people of Fiji on a basis consistent with the principles that have guided the Commonwealth. They agreed that the Commonwealth would, if requested, be ready to offer its good offices towards such a resolution and, on such basis, if the circumstances warrant, to consider the question of Fiji's membership of the Commonwealth if asked to do so.''

This outcome is entirely consistent with my Government's own policies. Indeed it reflects the initiatives which I took at the meeting of South Pacific Forum leaders at Vancouver preceding CHOGM, and in the lengthy discussions at and during the conference.
Australia deplores the overturning of democracy in Fiji.

We believe we can speak for all Australians in saying that the friendship of Australia toward the people of Fiji is undiminished. We are deeply concerned not only about the political uncertainty now facing Fiji but about the economic costs and the disruption to Fiji's international relations which have resulted.

We recognise, as a matter of fact, that the future political system in Fiji will be different from the one existing before the military intervention. But we attach high importance to the evolution of a political structure which represents a return to basic democratic principle and which recognises and protects human rights.
We hope that all those leaders in Fiji capable of exerting influence and playing a role to that end will do so.

We consider it to be a matter for the people of Fiji to determine their political path. Inevitably, however, Australia's relationship with Fiji-both in terms of its general quality and in terms of specifics such as aid and defence co-operation-must be affected by the direction Fiji takes internally. Put bluntly we could not have the same relationship with a military dictatorship as with a representative civilian government.

We support the Commonwealth, as we earlier supported the South Pacific Forum, in the offer to assist Fiji in its present political difficulties. Those offers are on the table and I believe deserve close consideration by the authorities in Fiji.

I turn now to southern Africa, the political issue of greatest importance for the Vancouver meeting as a whole. Aside from the meeting in London last August of seven Commonwealth countries, Australia included, Vancouver provided the first opportunity for Commonwealth leaders to assess events since the major decisions taken at Nassau in 1985.

In the intervening period the situation within South Africa itself has deteriorated; instability and violence had increased; the Government had become more oppressive; the efforts by the Commonwealth Eminent Persons Group to facilitate dialogue and negotiation had been rejected by the South African authorities; South Africa had put increased pressure on neighbouring states; the southern African region as a whole had faced a combination of military and economic destabilisation; and the root cause of all of this, the abhorrent system of apartheid, remained fundamentally unchanged.

At Vancouver we discussed the issues against that background, and Heads of Government issued a Statement on Southern Africa and Program of Action. This document makes the important judgment that ``in spite of the Pretoria regime's increased intransigence since Nassau, we remain convinced that only through negotiations can catastrophe be averted''. It calls for the South African Government to accept the Negotiating Concept developed by the Eminent Persons Group which remains as valid today as it was when the Group put it forward.
The decisions of Vancouver, including on sanctions, need to be seen in that context: not as contradicting dialogue and negotiation but as promoting them.

The approach adopted at Vancouver was to secure the universal adoption of the measures which have now been put in place by most Commonwealth countries and others including the United States and the Nordic countries. At the initiative of Australia an expert study will be undertaken of South Africa's relationship with the international financial system, a system which has itself imposed significant pressure on the South African economy in the past.
I wish to comment briefly on the effectiveness of sanctions, since clearly this was an issue which, at Vancouver as in the past, divided Britain from the rest.

Ironically, and most uncomfortably for those who deny that sanctions are effective, at the time CHOGM was meeting the South African Government itself conceded that sanctions were hurting. On 15 October the South African Finance Minister, speaking at the National Party's Natal Congress, said that the negative economic effect of sanctions should not be underestimated.

South Africa had, he said, accumulated billions of dollars worth of non-productive assets, such as oil, which had to be stockpiled because of sanctions. He asked his audience to imagine what could be done if, for example, South Africa had certainty regarding supplies of oil and other strategic commodities and was able to release these reserves to finance development and infrastructure.

Moreover, critics of sanctions tend to have a simplistic view. They seem to be saying that unless the measures adopted bring an economy to its knees then they have failed. But the Government has indicated frequently that the aim is not to bring South Africa to its knees but to bring it to its senses. Changes in public attitudes and in the attitudes of a Government as locked into the past as are South Africa's, may well take time. Far from helping this process, easing up on external pressure would be utterly counter-productive. As the Eminent Persons Group report says ``if the South African Government comes to the conclusion that it would always remain protected from such measures the process of change in South Africa is unlikely to increase in momentum and the descent into violence would be accelerated''.

Nor can the view be sustained that the Commonwealth is not in a position to exert significant pressure. That ignores the catalytic role of the Commonwealth in raising the consciousness of the international community and in encouraging measures on the part of the major economic powers.

Opponents of sanctions also seem to ignore the fact that some situations are so abhorrent that it would be inadequate simply to declare them wrong, without making a tangible expression of that abhorrence. They would leave the Western countries with no concrete means of demonstrating support for those striving for change in South Africa, support which they have every right to expect from countries espousing liberal democratic principles.

But it is also a matter of self-interest. To refuse to lend forthright support is a recipe for alienating from the West the future leaders of the post-apartheid South Africa. It is to undermine those leaders of the struggle who have the moderate objective of political equality, social justice and economic prosperity for all citizens regardless of race.

CHOGM also addressed what the Eminent Persons Group appropriately called ``the external face of apartheid'', the security and economic problems of South Africa's neighbours. We decided to initiate an enhanced program of coordinated Commonwealth assistance. This will be directed towards the Front Line and neighbouring states, particularly Mozambique.
I note in this context that the Government in the last Budget provided for an increased program of assistance to the southern African region amounting to $55 million over 3 years.

Another important element of the CHOGM decisions was a new effort to reach into South Africa through, among other measures, the provision of assistance to the victims of apartheid such as detainees and their families and support to the trade union movement.

I draw attention also to the establishment of a mechanism by the Commonwealth to provide high level impetus and guidance on the southern African issues between meetings of Heads of Government. This will take the form of a committee of Foreign Ministers which will meet periodically. Australia will be represented on that committee.

As I said at the outset, CHOGM addressed many other political and economic issues of interest to Australia ranging from the welcome improvement in East/West relations, through prospects for progress in arms control to such important regional issues as New Caledonia and international economic questions such as debt. Our decisions are reflected in the Communique.

Finally, I note the reaffirmation at Vancouver of the value of functional cooperation between Commonwealth countries. It is important to recognise that of course there is a limit to how much the Commonwealth should do or how widely it should spread its activities, particularly at a time of tight budgetary restraint. My Government does not take the view that Commonwealth programs should forever expand. But equally we do recognise that there are areas where the Commonwealth can and does play a valuable role.

In that connection I mention the steps which the Vancouver meeting decided to take to facilitate distance education. This has real promise and potential. Australia, with our experience in distance learning, should be able both to contribute to and benefit from the co-operative arrangements which are to be established.
In closing I pay tribute to Brian Mulroney, and the people of Vancouver and the province of British Columbia, for their hospitality during what was a very well-run and friendly meeting.
IRELAND AND YUGOSLAVIA

My visit was also devoted to the task of forging closer links with two European nations which are of particular importance to Australia: Ireland and Yugoslavia. About one in three Australians today claim Irish ancestry, since there has been a steady flow of immigrants to Australia from Ireland dating from the first day of European settlement of this land.

More recently, significant numbers of Yugoslavian people have chosen Australia as their new home. These links of kinship with Ireland and Yugoslavia were reflected in the warmth of the welcome I received in both countries.
Nor are our ties with these countries merely of an emotional nature.

We share a number of valuable commercial interests and we are affected by the broad range of pressing global political issues. I took the opportunity in my discussions with leaders in both countries of exploring Australian concerns in these fields.
Ireland

Nobody who has ever sung an Australian folk song, become involved in Australian politics or participated in Australian sport could have done so without recognising the profound and generous contribution of the Irish people to the development of our nation. Outside Ireland itself, there is no country more Irish than Australia. As I told the Irish Taoiseach, Mr Charles Haughey, on my arrival at Dublin airport, I felt as if I had arrived home, so friendly and familiar was the atmosphere.

As Australians approach our Bicentennial, it is appropriate that we look back over two hundred years of Irish involvement in the broadest spectrum of our economic, political, religious and cultural life. And as we continue in the creation of a truly multicultural society, it is appropriate we recall the struggle for equality of opportunity and cultural freedom fought by the Irish, who constituted our first and largest ethnic minority.

On my visit to Ireland, I discussed these links of kinship in an address at University College Dublin. This college is the home of the Keith Cameron School of Australian History, a professorship jointly funded by the Australian Government and Mr Tony O'Reilly, a generous benefactor of Ireland and Irish culture.

I also had the pleasure of witnessing contemporary manifestations of the Irish-Australian heritage at Croke Park Dublin-namely the first Test match between Irish and Australian footballers. Though Australia lost by a narrow margin, it was a highly enjoyable game of football. I was pleased to note that the Australians have since gone on to win the series. I wish the organisers well in their continuing efforts to seek a compromise form of rules to allow the unique Australian and Gaelic codes to be contested at the international level.

The Irish Dail, or Parliament, gave me the honour of an invitation to address them. This was only the third time the Dail had extended such an invitation to a foreign head of government, my two predecessors being President Reagan and the late President Kennedy. As I told the Dail in my address on October 21, their choice of two Americans and one Australian reflects the historical truth that though Ireland is the most anti-imperialist of nations, it is the head of a spiritual empire-an empire of Irish kinship, character and commitment-of which Australia and the United States are the principal provinces.

Australia's historical links with Ireland are particularly important as we approach our Bicentenary. I thanked the Irish Government on a number of occasions for its generous involvement in our Bicentennial celebrations which will include the gift of microfilm records of the 40,000 Irish men and women transported to Australia from Ireland in the eighteenth and nineteenth century.
However it would have been inappropriate if my speech to the Dail, or indeed my entire visit to Ireland, dwelt solely on the historical elements of our relationship.

As medium sized industrial economies, which share and nourish the same commitment to democracy, Australia and Ireland can bring important perspectives to resolving the range of pressing contemporary issues we face.

Australia has chosen the path of a firm alliance relationship with the United States and is in the process of enmeshing itself in the dynamic Pacific Rim, while Ireland has chosen neutrality and membership of the European community. But both countries share the same aspirations for peace, arms control, human rights, the principles of national self-determination and the elimination of apartheid.

Just as successive Irish Governments have been committed to enhancing the prospects for international peace-through, for example, their contribution to United Nations peace keeping forces-they have been dedicated also to the achievement of peace on their own borders.
I told the Dail that Australia supported the efforts of the Irish and British Governments through the Anglo-Irish Agreement, to end the communal strife in Northern Ireland.

And I know all Honourable Members would support me in giving an assurance to the Irish Government that we would do all within our power to discourage any Australian citizen from adding in any way to the violence in Northern Ireland.
On economic issues, the Taoiseach and I discussed strategies of consensus and cooperation through which our nation could create the self-discipline needed to meet the economic challenges we face.

We found common ground in the observation that countries like Australia and Ireland cannot afford to live beyond their means. Governments must take the hard decisions to reorder our priorities, reduce deficits, attack indebtedness, tighten spending and question the assumptions of the past in order to secure long-term economic health.

In my speech to the Dail, I added that all these hard adjustment decisions would avail a nation little if it faced a hostile international environment-particularly one which damaged the international trading system.

Consistent then with the overall thrust of my trip, I told the Irish, as members of the European Community, that the EC's policies of agricultural subsidisation were damaging not just countries like Australia but ultimately, were damaging the perpetrators of protectionism as well.
Yugoslavia

Australia and Yugoslavia have an active and constructive relationship based in particular around Yugoslavia's pivotal position in East-West relations and its prominent role in the Non-Aligned Movement and, on a bilateral basis, around the 300,000-strong community of Yugoslavian descent now living in Australia.

My discussions in Belgrade with Prime Minister Branko Mikulic focused largely on economic and trade matters. They were frank, informal and very friendly. I outlined to the Prime Minister the Australian position on international trade and the efforts we had been making in a number of fora, including my address to the GATT, towards liberalising world trade. The Prime Minister indicated that Yugoslavia shared Australia's concerns and supported our efforts to free up world trade, especially in agriculture, since Yugoslavia had been suffering from the United States-European Communities subsidies war.

In the area of domestic economic policy, the Prime Minister and I discussed our respective policies of economic stabilisation and economic reform. I was particularly indebted to Prime Minister Mikulic for his extremely frank and detailed exposition of the reforms being pursued in Yugoslavia in an effort to remedy the very significant economic problems facing the country. The reforms they are undertaking are clearly market oriented. They are designed to overhaul the economy and particularly, to ease the country's significant external debt problem.

In my judgment the Prime Minister's exposition reflected a sound understanding of the nature of the problems and the remedies that are necessary. The explanation consisted in part of saying that Yugoslavia had been living beyond its means during the 1970s and that inevitably, therefore, adjustments had to be made. He referred to the fact that during the 1980s real wages had fallen in the order of 25 per cent.

Prime Minister Mikulic expressed his frustration and that of Yugoslavia, that many Western countries seem still to regard Yugoslavia as part of the Eastern bloc. He pointed out that they are not; they are non-aligned.

He explained for example that for 1987 to date, more than half of Yugoslavia's trade was with the West. Yet this perception, he said, had been damaging for the prospects of economic co-operation between Yugoslavia and the West.

I undertook to the Prime Minister that I would do all we could to dispel the misconceptions held by Western countries. In particular, I undertook to talk to our friends in the United States to the effect that it would make sense for them to be more forthcoming in economic relations with Yugoslavia.

Prime Minister Mikulic and I agreed to formalise our bilateral economic relations to seek to enhance trade, and to extend joint ventures-building on the success of Rudi Cajavec's enterprise with the Telectronics company of Australia to assemble and to manufacture Australian designed heart pacemakers for use in Yugoslavia and for export from Yugoslavia. We also will be looking at ways of promoting scientific and technical co-operation. We have agreed that there will be an initial meeting of officials to be held at the earliest practicable opportunity. That meeting of officials will then seek to formalise the form that the annual meetings between our two countries will take.

The presence in Australia of so many people of Yugoslavian origin is overwhelmingly a positive link between our two countries. But as I told Mr Mikulic, it would be foolish of both sides not to recognise that on occasion it can create some awkwardness in our bilateral relations.

In exercising their right to free speech in Australia, people may say things which touch old wounds and scrape sensitive nerves. We are determined to maintain this right of people to speak freely even if they may say things with which we disagree. That is their right as free Australians, as long as they do not move towards violence, which the Australian Government will not tolerate.

Although this is a problem that is, thankfully, diminishing with time, it still occasionally occurs. What is encouraging is that in recent instances, the recognition by both of us of the strength and importance of our friendship, together with the discretion and commonsense shown by the respective governments, have enabled us to find solutions. Yugoslavia's leading role in the non-aligned movement and its strategic position and independent approach give it a particularly interesting perspective on issues of importance to Australia.

In Belgrade, I had the opportunity to exchange views on foreign policy issues of common interest with President Lazar Mojsov, a distinguished international statesman. We had useful discussions on East-West relations, the Middle East and Persian Gulf, and Indochina.
THE AUSTRALIAN-AMERICAN ALLIANCE

Honourable Members will recall that the United States Secretary of State George Shultz and Secretary for Defence, Caspar Weinberger, visited Sydney in June for bilateral Ministerial talks with Mr Hayden, Mr Beazley and myself. Those talks confirmed the strength of the alliance between our two countries and the close and friendly nature of the Australia-United States relationship.
On my recent overseas visit, I had the opportunity to spend several hours in discussion with Mr Shultz, in and around San Francisco on 10 and 11 October.

I found these talks particularly useful. They took place against the background of important developments in East-West relations, the Asia-Pacific region, the Middle East and Persian Gulf, and the world economy.
I drew Mr Shultz's attention to the speech I had made in San Diego on US trade policy and Australia-American relations, to which I have already referred.

We discussed developments in the Persian Gulf and, in the light of the Secretary of State's forthcoming visit to Egypt and Israel, which has since of course taken place, the prospect for an International Conference on the Middle East.

We exchanged views about the Philippines and reiterated the firm support of both our Governments for President Aquino. I gave Mr Shultz our appreciation of developments in the South Pacific. Without seeking to exaggerate the situation, I expressed the view that the overthrow of parliamentary democracy in Fiji and France's insensitive policy in New Caledonia were among the factors which had made it a less stable region than was the case at the beginning of the decade.

Mr Shultz previewed for me his visit to Moscow, which took place last week. From Australia's point of view, I expressed the importance we attach to the conclusion of an INF Agreement, both for its own sake and as a step towards reductions in strategic nuclear arsenals and other areas of arms control.

The Secretary of State very kindly offered to send a member of his delegation to brief me on the outcome of his talks with Mr Gorbachev and Mr Shevardnadze, immediately they were concluded. Accordingly, Mr Tom Simons, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, a Soviet specialist, flew straight from Moscow to Dubrovnik and gave me and my party a detailed and very informative account of the meetings and some interesting impressions of the important developments now taking place in the USSR.
Overall, my visit confirmed very clearly that Australia's relationship with the United States is in excellent shape.

Australia must continue to push hard on the issue of trade liberalisation. I am happy to report that my efforts overseas to make progress on this front were well received. Although negotiations will inevitably be slow and painstaking, I believe Australia has established the credibility of its voice in urging an early harvest of results.

I am also pleased to report that our role remains a prominent one in that valuable global association, the Commonwealth. Our alliance relationship with the United States remains soundly based. And our friendly bilateral relationship with Ireland and Yugoslavia have been put on a new and even more constructive footing.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 October 1987 (Hansard, page 1210), Senator Chaney asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations to the very belated reply I received last week from the Minister for Industrial Relations on the subject of severance pay in the building industry. In particular, I draw to his attention the Minister's indication that the Government would not endorse the severance pay scheme unless the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was satisfied that it did not breach the wages principles. The Minister also indicated that unless the scheme was modified to fit within the wage principles, the Commonwealth would not agree to its payment on government projects. I note the Minister's acknowledgement that the existing scheme does not adhere to the national wage case principles, and ask him to agree that as a matter of simple logic it must therefore be in breach of the Government's code of conduct. If he agrees with this simple proposition, I ask him whether the Government intends to take action to exclude those who have breached the code of conduct from future government works; and, if not, why not.
In my reply I undertook to refer the question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:

As previously advised in my answer to Senator Chaney, Senate Hansard, 23 October 1987, page 1196, I wrote to the parties advising them that the proposed redundancy scheme could not be supported by the Government in its present form. I requested the parties to reconsider the proposed scheme to ensure it is bona fide and capable of receiving Commission endorsement.
I have subsequently been advised by the parties that they are committed to the introduction of a genuine scheme and will be addressing matters of concern raised by the Government.

I reiterate that the Government has no objection to a genuine scheme that is endorsed by the Commission and accepts the parties' commitment to work towards this end. Accordingly the Government considers that any application of the Code of Conduct would be premature at this point of time.
